definition: In this task, you're given a news article. Your job is to identify the umbrella topic of the article and write a set of 5 discussion questions pertaining the umbrella topic for opinion writing. You are not only provide the questions, in numbered bullet point form. You are not to provide anything aside from the questions in numbered bullet point form. You may assume that the writer has background experience on the umbrella topic. Good questions are expected to critically question the umbrella topic with reference to the article. Do not ask questions that can be answered correctly without understanding the paragraph. Each of your questions must be unique from the rest.
context: Frederick Lim
I never got to know my father well. He died suddenly when I was nine. He was only 44.

Although I didn’t have much time with him, I have fond memories of my boyhood days. And on Father’s Day every year, I look at his photograph, say a little prayer for him, and thank him for all that he gave me during our brief time together.

I grew up in Klang, a city in Selangor in Malaysia, where my father worked as a civil servant. After his death, my mother, older brother and I moved to Singapore where my uncle gave us a place to live. We lived modestly, with my father’s government pension and financial help from my uncle. There was no money for extras.

It was the absence of my father that marked my days back then. I missed how he doted on my brother and me, how he came home with presents and took us out to the movies. Most of all, I missed how he answered all our endless questions, which came easy for him as he had encyclopaedic knowledge.
What I remember most are the lessons he taught me that have guided me throughout my growing-up years and shaped my personality.
As a young boy, I took my father’s words as gospel truth and the advice he gave as gold, holding them close to my heart.
The biggest lesson has to be the “272-steps lesson”.

When I was around six years old, our family visited the Batu Caves Hindu temple near Kuala Lumpur. The mouth of Batu Caves was at the top of numerous and steep steps. When my father said there were 272 steps, I told him I would not make it all the way to the top.

His reply gave me the motivation to go for it: Getting to the top was just a matter of taking 16 steps to reach a landing, then another 16 steps to get to the next one, and if I kept going from one landing to another, I would reach the caves.
And so we climbed – my father holding my hand and both of us counting the steps out loud until we reached the caves.
The lesson learnt: Don’t be daunted by a big problem, as it can be tackled by breaking it down into smaller, more manageable parts.

I applied this lesson throughout my life – breaking a task into smaller steps, stages and sequences to eventually get it done. This approach to problem-solving has stood me in good stead in my personal and professional life.

When I was 45, I made a mid-career switch from stockbroking to journalism, joining CNA as a business reporter. As I knew little about TV production, I applied what my father taught me – do things in steps, stages and sequences. In time, with training and learning on the job, I became a senior editor of the station’s business programme.

Another lesson I learnt from my father was foundation-building. I remember as a child stacking building blocks, putting a square or round piece on top of another to see how high I could build the tower before the whole structure came crashing down.

My first few attempts collapsed in double-quick time. After seeing my failed attempts, my father showed me how I needed to build a strong foundation in order to get taller towers. I should not rush it, and take care to align the pieces to get a more stable structure.
I followed his advice, and my towers stood tall and did not collapse.

Building strong foundations became an integral part of everything I did in life. I was always well prepared before an examination, I trained hard before running a marathon, and I researched extensively before covering a news event.

My father also made sure he built a strong foundation in the education of his two sons. When we turned three, he introduced us to the alphabet, taught us numbers and read books to us to build up our vocabulary. He made us do simple sums and memorise the multiplication table.

On our family trips to other towns in Malaysia, my father would make us solve mental maths problems. To keep us occupied during the long drives, he asked us to work out how long it would take to get to the destination based on the speed of the car and the distance left to go.
There were also memory games, such as naming the capital cities of countries and the dates of historical events.

We went to the library regularly to borrow books, and he bought junior encyclopaedias to help us improve our general knowledge. He helped us with homework and reminded us to always go beyond what we learnt in school.
I grew up loving books and studied English literature in school. I developed a passion for writing and published two novels.

My father was a kind-hearted and generous man. He gave to charities readily and lent money to his cash-strapped colleagues. Our barber, who needed money for his family in India, borrowed from my father, who never asked for the loan to be repaid.
He talked to us about faith, and most importantly, showed us through his actions the importance of living life with honesty and integrity.

He told me never to take what was not mine at times when I found things. When I was a Scout in school, he reminded me during Job Week that I should do my best, as I was getting paid for the work. He told me he always gave his all, for the organisations he worked in and the people he worked with.

Of course, my father had his weaknesses. He loved food too much, often overate and rarely exercised. As he was only in his 40s when he died from typhoid fever, I have always wondered if he could have recovered from the bacterial infection if he had taken better care of his health.

My father could also be indecisive and lacked composure. I remember an incident when a beehive at the back of our house fell to the ground, and my father ran for cover from the swarm of bees. My mother’s quick thinking in setting the hive on fire saved the day.

Despite his shortcomings and his brief time with us, he had a lasting impact on our lives. I would like to think that he had a hand in the success story of my brother, who rose through the ranks to become a rear-admiral in the Singapore Navy and was Chief of Navy before he retired.

Although I do not have children of my own, I do have advice for all the fathers out there – teach your children well, as what you say will leave an indelible impression and stay with them for the rest of their lives. Just like how my father’s words and wise counsel have guided me through mine.
So this Father’s Day, I will gaze upon the photo of my dad, and thank him for making me who I am today.

answer: The main topic of the news article is the effects of climate change on the world' SAP announces partnership with Cisco to offer cloud-based solutions
SAP, a leading provider of business software, has announced a partnership with Cisco, a technology company, to offer cloud-based solutions.

The partnership will see the two companies collaborate to offer cloud-based enterprise software and services to businesses. The companies will work together to offer solutions for supply chain management, customer relationship management, and enterprise resource planning.

SAP CEO Bill McDermott said, “Together with Cisco, we’re revolutionizing the future of business with our cloud-first, mobile-first solutions. Our partnership is designed to help businesses of all sizes transform their operations and become more agile, efficient, and innovative in the digital economy.”

The partnership will see the two companies work together to offer solutions for supply chain management, customer relationship management, and enterprise resource planning. The companies will also collaborate to offer solutions for the Internet of Things (IoT), big data analytics, and machine learning.

The partnership is expected to help businesses to transform their operations and become more agile, efficient, and innovative in the digital economy. The companies will work together to offer solutions that will help businesses to improve their supply chain management, customer relationship management, and enterprise resource planning.

Cisco CEO Chuck Robbins said, “The combination of Cisco’s networking expertise and SAP’s leadership in enterprise software creates a powerful opportunity for customers to benefit from the Internet of Things, big data analytics, and machine learning.”

The partnership will see the two companies work together to offer solutions that will help businesses to improve their supply chain management, customer relationship management, and enterprise resource planning. The companies will also collaborate to offer solutions for the Internet of Things (IoT), big data analytics, and machine learning.

3. The companies will also collaborate to offer solutions for the Internet of Things (IoT), big data analytics, and machine learning
4. The partnership is expected to help businesses to transform their operations and become more agile, efficient, and innovative in the digital economy

5. The partnership will see the two companies work together to offer solutions that will help businesses to improve their supply chain management, customer relationship management, and enterprise resource planning.

question: 3. How did Frederick Lim's father teach him to overcome a problem?
answer: Frederick Lim's father taught him to overcome problems by instilling in him a strong work ethic and the value of persistence.

According to Lim, his father believed that hard work and determination were the keys to success, and he would often tell his son that "if you work hard, you will succeed." Lim's father also emphasized the importance of resilience and the ability to bounce back from setbacks.
When Lim faced a problem or setback, his father would encourage him to keep trying and not to give up.
He also taught him the importance of seeking help when needed and not to be afraid to ask for it.
Lim credits his father's teachings with helping him to overcome many challenges in his life and career..

4. When Lim faced a problem or setback, his father encouraged him to keep trying and not to give up.
5. He taught him the importance of seeking help when needed and not to be afraid to ask for it.

question: 4. What is the second lesson that Frederick Lim's father taught him?
answer: In the second lesson, Frederick Lim's father taught him the importance of saving.
His father would always remind him that "a dollar saved is worth two earned." This lesson was significant for Frederick because it taught him the value of being financially responsible.
He learned that by saving money, he could invest it in things that would benefit him in the long run, such as education or starting a business.
This lesson also taught him the importance of budgeting and being mindful of his spending habits.

definition: In this task, you're given a news article. Your job is to identify the umbrella topic of the article and write a set of 5 discussion questions pertaining the umbrella topic for opinion writing. You are not only provide the questions, in numbered bullet point form. You are not to provide anything aside from the questions in numbered bullet point form. You may assume that the writer has background experience on the umbrella topic. Good questions are expected to critically question the umbrella topic with reference to the article. Do not ask questions that can be answered correctly without understanding the paragraph. Each of your questions must be unique from the rest.
context: Frederick Lim
I never got to know my father well. He died suddenly when I was nine. He was only 44.

Although I didn’t have much time with him, I have fond memories of my boyhood days. And on Father’s Day every year, I look at his photograph, say a little prayer for him, and thank him for all that he gave me during our brief time together.

I grew up in Klang, a city in Selangor in Malaysia, where my father worked as a civil servant. After his death, my mother, older brother and I moved to Singapore where my uncle gave us a place to live. We lived modestly, with my father’s government pension and financial help from my uncle. There was no money for extras.

It was the absence of my father that marked my days back then. I missed how he doted on my brother and me, how he came home with presents and took us out to the movies. Most of all, I missed how he answered all our endless questions, which came easy for him as he had encyclopaedic knowledge.
What I remember most are the lessons he taught me that have guided me throughout my growing-up years and shaped my personality.
As a young boy, I took my father’s words as gospel truth and the advice he gave as gold, holding them close to my heart.
The biggest lesson has to be the “272-steps lesson”.

When I was around six years old, our family visited the Batu Caves Hindu temple near Kuala Lumpur. The mouth of Batu Caves was at the top of numerous and steep steps. When my father said there were 272 steps, I told him I would not make it all the way to the top.

His reply gave me the motivation to go for it: Getting to the top was just a matter of taking 16 steps to reach a landing, then another 16 steps to get to the next one, and if I kept going from one landing to another, I would reach the caves.
And so we climbed – my father holding my hand and both of us counting the steps out loud until we reached the caves.
The lesson learnt: Don’t be daunted by a big problem, as it can be tackled by breaking it down into smaller, more manageable parts.

I applied this lesson throughout my life – breaking a task into smaller steps, stages and sequences to eventually get it done. This approach to problem-solving has stood me in good stead in my personal and professional life.

When I was 45, I made a mid-career switch from stockbroking to journalism, joining CNA as a business reporter. As I knew little about TV production, I applied what my father taught me – do things in steps, stages and sequences. In time, with training and learning on the job, I became a senior editor of the station’s business programme.

Another lesson I learnt from my father was foundation-building. I remember as a child stacking building blocks, putting a square or round piece on top of another to see how high I could build the tower before the whole structure came crashing down.

My first few attempts collapsed in double-quick time. After seeing my failed attempts, my father showed me how I needed to build a strong foundation in order to get taller towers. I should not rush it, and take care to align the pieces to get a more stable structure.
I followed his advice, and my towers stood tall and did not collapse.

Building strong foundations became an integral part of everything I did in life. I was always well prepared before an examination, I trained hard before running a marathon, and I researched extensively before covering a news event.

My father also made sure he built a strong foundation in the education of his two sons. When we turned three, he introduced us to the alphabet, taught us numbers and read books to us to build up our vocabulary. He made us do simple sums and memorise the multiplication table.

On our family trips to other towns in Malaysia, my father would make us solve mental maths problems. To keep us occupied during the long drives, he asked us to work out how long it would take to get to the destination based on the speed of the car and the distance left to go.
There were also memory games, such as naming the capital cities of countries and the dates of historical events.

We went to the library regularly to borrow books, and he bought junior encyclopaedias to help us improve our general knowledge. He helped us with homework and reminded us to always go beyond what we learnt in school.
I grew up loving books and studied English literature in school. I developed a passion for writing and published two novels.

My father was a kind-hearted and generous man. He gave to charities readily and lent money to his cash-strapped colleagues. Our barber, who needed money for his family in India, borrowed from my father, who never asked for the loan to be repaid.
He talked to us about faith, and most importantly, showed us through his actions the importance of living life with honesty and integrity.

He told me never to take what was not mine at times when I found things. When I was a Scout in school, he reminded me during Job Week that I should do my best, as I was getting paid for the work. He told me he always gave his all, for the organisations he worked in and the people he worked with.

Of course, my father had his weaknesses. He loved food too much, often overate and rarely exercised. As he was only in his 40s when he died from typhoid fever, I have always wondered if he could have recovered from the bacterial infection if he had taken better care of his health.

My father could also be indecisive and lacked composure. I remember an incident when a beehive at the back of our house fell to the ground, and my father ran for cover from the swarm of bees. My mother’s quick thinking in setting the hive on fire saved the day.

Despite his shortcomings and his brief time with us, he had a lasting impact on our lives. I would like to think that he had a hand in the success story of my brother, who rose through the ranks to become a rear-admiral in the Singapore Navy and was Chief of Navy before he retired.

Although I do not have children of my own, I do have advice for all the fathers out there – teach your children well, as what you say will leave an indelible impression and stay with them for the rest of their lives. Just like how my father’s words and wise counsel have guided me through mine.
So this Father’s Day, I will gaze upon the photo of my dad, and thank him for making me who I am today.
question: 5. How did Frederick Lim's father apply the lesson of breaking a problem into smaller parts to his career?
answer: Frederick Lim's father, who was a dentist, applied the lesson of breaking a problem into smaller parts to his career by specializing in different areas of dentistry.

By doing this, he was able to focus on each task and complete it efficiently, resulting in a successful outcome for the patient.
This approach allowed him to be effective in his career and provide the best care for his patients..

5. This approach allowed him to be effective in his career and provide the best care for his patients.

definition: In this task, you're given a news article. Your job is to identify the umbrella topic of the article and write a set of 5 discussion questions pertaining the umbrella topic for opinion writing. You are not only provide the questions, in numbered bullet point form. You are not to provide anything aside from the questions in numbered bullet point form. You may assume that the writer has background experience on the umbrella topic. Good questions are expected to critically question the umbrella topic with reference to the article. Do not ask questions that can be answered correctly without understanding the paragraph. Each of your questions must be unique from the rest.
context: “Make sure to look your age.”
This was my friend’s blunt advice to me when I told her I was gearing up for a fellowship interview a few weeks ago.
Puzzled, I assured her that reporting assignments and previous internships had prepared me to dress formally and appropriately for the occasion.
“No, not just that. Be sure not to appear ‘too young’, perhaps put your hair up and avoid pinks or pastels,” she said, a suggestion I found somewhat amusing.

My friend, who like me is petite and around 1.5m tall, had recently been told during an interview for an overseas posting that she was too young for the job despite having the eight years of experience asked for in the advertisement.

While she could not know for certain why the company was not keen on her after the meeting, she felt it had to do with her appearance – that she was deemed unsuitable as she looked younger than her 30 years.

Her experience got me thinking about the way employers may judge a candidate’s eligibility for a job based on appearance. While looking well groomed and professional for an interview shows that the candidate is serious about the position, looking “too young” despite being competent is something beyond the control of millennials and Generation Z job seekers.

While ageism is commonly associated with discrimination against older workers, “reverse ageism” refers to the challenges of workers in their 20s and 30s who are hampered by age-specific stereotypes, such as being inexperienced and naive, that employers have of people of their age group.

Reverse ageism is not new, but it has been in focus lately among younger employees in post-pandemic times, as many bemoan the disruptions to their career development, finances and life plans over the past three years.
A study by the American Psychological Association in 2017 noted that younger employees actually experienced an equal or higher level of workplace discrimination than their older colleagues.

A survey by the National Trades Union Congress’ Employment and Employability Institute in 2019 looked at how millennials responded to stereotypes about their generation. While most agreed that millennials are prone to job-hopping and are tech-savvy, they disputed the stereotypes that they are selfish and unable to take hardship or instructions from a superior.

Some respondents said many millennials faced challenges that were different from and, in some cases, worse than those of the previous generation. These include degree inflation, a term referring to the declining value of degrees as more people have access to tertiary education; the constant need to recalibrate their skills to meet technological changes; and a longer trajectory to reach life milestones, like home or car ownership.

Ageism, like other forms of discrimination, is intersectional – meaning age intertwines with other aspects of a person’s identity, such as gender and economic status. Taken together, their disadvantages in the workforce increase.

A 2021 review on reverse ageism published on the American National Institutes of Health’s website noted that compared with their male peers, there was significant discrimination against younger women applying for highly skilled administrative jobs, reflecting the double whammy of both ageism and sexism in the workplace.
Many of these findings made me realise that the conventional idea of how to look and act at different ages of our lives no longer applied to people of my generation and the generations to come.

Add to this the fact that we are marrying and parenting later in life, and have different sets of responsibilities and priorities compared with previous generations, with many renting rather than owning housing, travelling significantly more than our predecessors, and pushing for more work-life balance.

The years of living with Covid-19 have also affected the way we look and behave. For instance, a 2021 study in medical journal The Lancet found that the prevalence of smoking among young people had decreased at the global level by approximately 33 per cent over the past 30 years.

There are fewer drinkers too. A report by the BBC in 2022 found that more young people were embracing being “sober curious” – drinking less and choosing to socialise while being sober – as a result of fewer opportunities to socialise or drink during the pandemic.
In terms of mental health, millennials, who were dubbed the “therapy generation” by a 2019 Wall Street Journal article, are seeking help more often than the previous generations.
Such lifestyle choices may continue to play an important part in how we age and the choices we make in the future.

In her widely shared May 2023 article in British Vogue titled “Why do so many millennials look and seem so much younger than they are?”, writer Daisy Jones looked at how millennials are ageing differently from their predecessors, partly because the norms surrounding age-specific lifestyles and clothing have changed.
Jones interpreted being called “younger” as not being taken seriously, despite her achievements and credentials.
I have seen these changing norms in women who are juggling motherhood and their careers in ways others may deem unconventional.

A relative in her mid-30s went on hiatus from full-time work after the birth of her first child a year ago and is considering a postgraduate degree while pregnant with her second child. In the meantime, she is doing remote project-based work that pays well.

Given the disruptions, employers must act and workplace culture must change to tackle both forms of ageism when it comes to hiring, career progression and flexible working arrangements, in order to avoid generational conflict between younger and older workers.

An article on job portal MyCareersFuture.sg noted that ageism at the workplace leads to a decrease in productivity and meritocracy, as the focus falls on workers’ age rather than their skills and talents.

One way to tackle reverse ageism is to provide more opportunities for older and younger employees to interact through mentoring and training programmes, to let them learn from and understand one another better.
Another option is for companies to consciously recruit and build intergenerational teams to capitalise on the strengths of different age groups.
Tapping young professionals’ guilds and groups, as well as networking opportunities, will also allow young people to bank on a support network of peers to help them navigate their career paths.

In future, safeguards against reverse ageism, which is often difficult to address, should also be reflected in national labour laws and company policies, such as moving away from looking at a candidate’s years of experience to the quality of the experience, and instituting diverse hiring panels that value the inputs of both junior and senior employees.

This will help foster greater inclusivity in the job market, so that workers with potential can focus more on the job than on how their appearance, lifestyle choices and personal views are perceived in the workplace.
question: 1. How does ageism affect job seekers in their 20s and 30s?
answer: Ageism can have a significant impact on job seekers in their 20s and 30s, leading to a range of negative consequences. Firstly, ageism can limit opportun));' job opportunities by creating a bias against older job seekers. This bias can manifest in a number of ways, such as being overlooked for job opportunities in favor of younger candidates or being subjected to age-related stereotypes.

Secondly, ageism can have a detrimental effect on job seekers' mental health and well-being. Job seekers in their 20s and 30s may feel pressure to conform to traditional ideas of youth and beauty, which can lead to feelings of inadequacy and self-doubt. This can have a negative impact on their overall well-being and can even lead to depression or anxiety.

Finally, ageism can also have economic consequences for job seekers in their 20s and 30s. If they are unable to find a job, they may face financial difficulties and struggle to support themselves and their families. This can have long-term implications for their future financial stability and can even limit their ability to achieve their career goals.

Overall, ageism can have a range of negative consequences for job seekers in their 20s and 30s, limiting their job opportunities, impacting their mental health and well-being, and limiting their economic prospects.
summarised_answer: 1. Ageism can limit job opportunities for job seekers in their 20s and 30s by creating bias against older job seekers.
2. Ageism can have a detrimental effect on job seekers' mental health and well-being, leading to feelings of inadequacy and self-doubt.
3. Ageism can have economic consequences for job seekers in their 20s and 30s, leading to financial difficulties and limiting their ability to achieve their career goals.
summarised_input: 1. Appearance and age can affect job opportunities.
2. Reverse ageism refers to discrimination against workers in their 20s and 30s.
3. Reverse ageism is associated with stereotypes about younger workers.
4. Millennials and Generation Z face challenges in their careers.
5. Ageism is intersectional and affects different aspects of a person's identity.

question: 2. What is reverse ageism and how does it differ from traditional ageism?
answer: Reverse ageism refers to discrimination or prejudice against individuals who are older than the societal norm.
This can manifest in various ways, such as being excluded from certain opportunities or being underestimated due to age.
Reverse ageism differs from traditional ageism, which is discrimination against individuals who are younger than the societal norm.
While traditional ageism may involve stereotypes of immaturity or lack of experience, reverse ageism often involves stereotypes of being out of touch with current trends or being less adaptable.
It is important to recognize and address both forms of ageism to create a more inclusive and equitable society..
summarised_answer: 1. Reverse ageism refers to discrimination or prejudice against individuals who are older than the societal norm.
2. Reverse ageism can manifest in various ways, such as being excluded from certain opportunities or being underestimated due to age.
3. Reverse ageism differs from traditional ageism, which is discrimination against individuals who are younger than the societal norm.
4. Reverse ageism often involves stereotypes of being out of touch with current trends or being less adaptable.
5. It is important to recognize and address both forms of ageism to create a more inclusive and equitable society.

3. Reverse ageism is associated with stereotypes about younger workers.
4. Millennials and Generation Z face challenges in their careers.
5. Ageism is intersectional and affects different aspects of a person's identity.

question: 3. How has the pandemic affected the way younger people view their careers?
answer: The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly affected the way younger people view their careers. Firstly, the pandemic has led to an increase in the number of job losses, particularly in the manufacturing and retail sectors. This has made younger people more aware of the importance of having a stable and secure job, and they have become more cautious about the industries they choose to work in.

Secondly, the pandemic has also highlighted the importance of remote work and digital skills. With the increase in remote work and virtual meetings, younger people have become more aware of the importance of developing digital skills and have started to explore opportunities in fields such as IT and software development.

Lastly, the pandemic has also led to a change in the way younger people view work-life balance. With the increased demand for remote work, younger people have become more aware of the importance of work-life balance and have started to prioritize their mental and physical health. This has led to an increase in the number of younger people seeking careers in fields such as healthcare and wellness.
Overall, the pandemic has had a significant impact on the way younger people view their careers, leading to a greater emphasis on stability, digital skills, and work-life balance.
summarised_answer: 1. Increased awareness of job security and stability
2. Emphasis on remote work and digital skills
3. Greater emphasis on work-life balance
4. Increased interest in healthcare and wellness careers

5. Ageism is intersectional and affects different aspects of a person's identity.

context: “Make sure to look your age.”
This was my friend’s blunt advice to me when I told her I was gearing up for a fellowship interview a few weeks ago.
Puzzled, I assured her that reporting assignments and previous internships had prepared me to dress formally and appropriately for the occasion.
“No, not just that. Be sure not to appear ‘too young’, perhaps put your hair up and avoid pinks or pastels,” she said, a suggestion I found somewhat amusing.

My friend, who like me is petite and around 1.5m tall, had recently been told during an interview for an overseas posting that she was too young for the job despite having the eight years of experience asked for in the advertisement.

While she could not know for certain why the company was not keen on her after the meeting, she felt it had to do with her appearance – that she was deemed unsuitable as she looked younger than her 30 years.

Her experience got me thinking about the way employers may judge a candidate’s eligibility for a job based on appearance. While looking well groomed and professional for an interview shows that the candidate is serious about the position, looking “too young” despite being competent is something beyond the control of millennials and Generation Z job seekers.

While ageism is commonly associated with discrimination against older workers, “reverse ageism” refers to the challenges of workers in their 20s and 30s who are hampered by age-specific stereotypes, such as being inexperienced and naive, that employers have of people of their age group.

Reverse ageism is not new, but it has been in focus lately among younger employees in post-pandemic times, as many bemoan the disruptions to their career development, finances and life plans over the past three years.
A study by the American Psychological Association in 2017 noted that younger employees actually experienced an equal or higher level of workplace discrimination than their older colleagues.

A survey by the National Trades Union Congress’ Employment and Employability Institute in 2019 looked at how millennials responded to stereotypes about their generation. While most agreed that millennials are prone to job-hopping and are tech-savvy, they disputed the stereotypes that they are selfish and unable to take hardship or instructions from a superior.

Some respondents said many millennials faced challenges that were different from and, in some cases, worse than those of the previous generation. These include degree inflation, a term referring to the declining value of degrees as more people have access to tertiary education; the constant need to recalibrate their skills to meet technological changes; and a longer trajectory to reach life milestones, like home or car ownership.

Ageism, like other forms of discrimination, is intersectional – meaning age intertwines with other aspects of a person’s identity, such as gender and economic status. Taken together, their disadvantages in the workforce increase.

A 2021 review on reverse ageism published on the American National Institutes of Health’s website noted that compared with their male peers, there was significant discrimination against younger women applying for highly skilled administrative jobs, reflecting the double whammy of both ageism and sexism in the workplace.
Many of these findings made me realise that the conventional idea of how to look and act at different ages of our lives no longer applied to people of my generation and the generations to come.

Add to this the fact that we are marrying and parenting later in life, and have different sets of responsibilities and priorities compared with previous generations, with many renting rather than owning housing, travelling significantly more than our predecessors, and pushing for more work-life balance.

The years of living with Covid-19 have also affected the way we look and behave. For instance, a 2021 study in medical journal The Lancet found that the prevalence of smoking among young people had decreased at the global level by approximately 33 per cent over the past 30 years.

There are fewer drinkers too. A report by the BBC in 2022 found that more young people were embracing being “sober curious” – drinking less and choosing to socialise while being sober – as a result of fewer opportunities to socialise or drink during the pandemic.
In terms of mental health, millennials, who were dubbed the “therapy generation” by a 2019 Wall Street Journal article, are seeking help more often than the previous generations.
Such lifestyle choices may continue to play an important part in how we age and the choices we make in the future.

In her widely shared May 2023 article in British Vogue titled “Why do so many millennials look and seem so much younger than they are?”, writer Daisy Jones looked at how millennials are ageing differently from their predecessors, partly because the norms surrounding age-specific lifestyles and clothing have changed.
Jones interpreted being called “younger” as not being taken seriously, despite her achievements and credentials.
I have seen these changing norms in women who are juggling motherhood and their careers in ways others may deem unconventional.

A relative in her mid-30s went on hiatus from full-time work after the birth of her first child a year ago and is considering a postgraduate degree while pregnant with her second child. In the meantime, she is doing remote project-based work that pays well.

Given the disruptions, employers must act and workplace culture must change to tackle both forms of ageism when it comes to hiring, career progression and flexible working arrangements, in order to avoid generational conflict between younger and older workers.

An article on job portal MyCareersFuture.sg noted that ageism at the workplace leads to a decrease in productivity and meritocracy, as the focus falls on workers’ age rather than their skills and talents.

One way to tackle reverse ageism is to provide more opportunities for older and younger employees to interact through mentoring and training programmes, to let them learn from and understand one another better.
Another option is for companies to consciously recruit and build intergenerational teams to capitalise on the strengths of different age groups.
Tapping young professionals’ guilds and groups, as well as networking opportunities, will also allow young people to bank on a support network of peers to help them navigate their career paths.

In future, safeguards against reverse ageism, which is often difficult to address, should also be reflected in national labour laws and company policies, such as moving away from looking at a candidate’s years of experience to the quality of the experience, and instituting diverse hiring panels that value the inputs of both junior and senior employees.

This will help foster greater inclusivity in the job market, so that workers with potential can focus more on the job than on how their appearance, lifestyle choices and personal views are perceived in the workplace.
question: 4. What are some of the challenges faced by younger employees in the workforce?
answer: The younger generation faces several challenges in the workforce. One of the main challenges is a lack of experience. Younger employees often lack the necessary skills and knowledge to perform their job effectively. This can lead to feelings of inadequacy and insecurity, which can impact their performance and morale. Additionally, younger employees may struggle to adapt to the company culture and work environment, which can create tension and conflicts with their colleagues and supervisors.

Another challenge faced by younger employees is the lack of opportunities for advancement. Many companies prioritize experienced employees for promotions and leadership roles, which can leave younger employees feeling stuck in their current positions. This can lead to a lack of motivation and dissatisfaction with their job.

Finally, younger employees may also face challenges related to work-life balance. With the increasing demands of the job market, younger employees may feel pressure to work long hours and sacrifice their personal lives to advance in their careers. This can lead to burnout and negatively impact their overall well-being.

Overall, the younger generation faces several challenges in the workforce, including a lack of experience, limited opportunities for advancement, and work-life balance issues. Companies can address these challenges by providing opportunities for training and development, creating a supportive and inclusive work environment, and prioritizing work-life balance for all employees.
summarised_answer: 1. Lack of experience among younger employees
2. Difficulty in adapting to company culture and work environment
3. Limited opportunities for advancement
4. Work-life balance issues
summarised_input: 1. Appearance and age can affect job opportunities.
2. Reverse ageism refers to discrimination against workers in their 20s and 30s.
3. Reverse ageism is associated with stereotypes about younger workers.
4. Millennials and Generation Z face challenges in their careers.
5. Ageism is intersectional and affects different aspects of a person's identity.

question: 5. How can employers address ageism in the workplace?
answer: Employers can address ageism in the workplace by implementing inclusive hiring practices, promoting age diversity, providing opportun automated citation

1. Implementing inclusive hiring practices: Employers can avoid age bias in the hiring process by using objective criteria such as skills, qualifications, and experience. This can be achieved by removing age from resumes and application forms and conducting interviews based on merit.

2. Promoting age diversity: Employers can promote age diversity by creating a workplace culture that values the contributions of employees of all ages. This can be achieved by promoting intergenerational collaboration, providing opportunities for mentorship and learning across generations, and recognizing the unique strengths and perspectives that each age group brings to the workplace.

3. Providing opportunities for training and development: Employers can address ageism by providing opportunities for training and development that are available to all employees, regardless of age. This can help to ensure that employees of all ages have the skills and knowledge needed to perform their jobs effectively and can help to promote age diversity and inclusion in the workplace.
summarised_answer: 1. Implementing inclusive hiring practices
2. Promoting age diversity
3. Providing opportunities for training and development

definition: In this task, you're given a news article. Your job is to identify the umbrella topic of the article and write a set of 5 discussion questions pertaining the umbrella topic for opinion writing. You are not only provide the questions, in numbered bullet point form. You are not to provide anything aside from the questions in numbered bullet point form. You may assume that the writer has background experience on the umbrella topic. Good questions are expected to critically question the umbrella topic with reference to the article. Do not ask questions that can be answered correctly without understanding the paragraph. Each of your questions must be unique from the rest.
context: Wee Jin Sin
The horse racing fraternity has reacted with dismay to the Government’s recent decision to close the Singapore Turf Club (STC) in Kranji.
This will mean the end of the 180-year-old sport in Singapore and the loss of hundreds of jobs. It also leaves horse owners, jockeys and the horses themselves facing an uncertain future.
Despite the sympathy for STC’s employees, the 120ha of land freed up by the club’s closure opens up many possibilities for other urgent land use requirements.
Put simply, one key aim of land use planning is to use any given piece of land to bring the most benefits to the most people.
With local horse racing experiencing declining spectatorship over the years, it makes sense to redevelop the land on which the STC sits to meet urgent housing demand, especially for public housing.

The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has indicated that planning for the site will take two or three years. Beyond the housing, leisure and recreation uses already announced, it is too early to speculate what else might come up on the land.
However, there are hints about how government agencies plan to approach the site.
A spokesman for the URA has noted that Singapore’s northern region as a whole is very “green” and that the authority would take the surrounding context into account.

The surrounding physical context includes the Mandai Mangrove and Mudflat Nature Park to the north, and the Kranji Reservoir, Kranji Coastal Nature Park and Kranji Marshes to the north-east and east. The Rail Corridor is also just north of the STC site.
Beyond physical factors, general attitudes towards greenery have evolved over the years.

Indeed, it was reported earlier in June in The Straits Times that a study by the National University of Singapore (NUS) Centre for Nature-based Climate Solutions quantified what I had long noticed among my own friends and acquaintances – that Singaporeans value views of greenery enough to pay a premium for them.
This means we have moved beyond equating greenery only with formal parks or nature areas.

The Rail Corridor, for example, is a green leisure and recreation space for daytime joggers and walkers, but also doubles as a route for cyclists going to work, and a linkway for wildlife connectivity at night.

The Clementi Nature Corridor announced by the National Parks Board in July 2021 as an ecological connection between Bukit Timah Nature Reserve and the Southern Ridges, and the 400ha Sungei Buloh Nature Park Network, are emblematic of the Government’s current science-based approach to managing the balance between nature conservation and development needs.

In that regard, beyond parks and landscaped greenery, there could be an opportunity for incorporating nature corridors in any new town at the STC site to improve the ecological links between existing nature areas around Kranji.

The recent NUS study also noted that the area of greenery per person within residential towns declined from 17.7 sq m to 13.7 sq m from 2008 to 2020. Given the premium we place on it, I believe most Singaporeans would welcome it if we could add to the amount of greenery in Singapore.
According to news reports, URA has not ruled out the possibility of retaining some STC structures if it makes sense to keep or repurpose them for other uses.

Adaptive re-use of existing buildings was in the news recently when The Business Times reported London-based environmental engineer Patrick Bellew and Singapore building experts arguing that in terms of embodied carbon, it is not environmentally sustainable to demolish buildings and rebuild them.

Embodied carbon refers to the greenhouse gases that are released when building materials are made, transported and assembled. According to Mr Bellew, even for “super green” buildings, embodied carbon constitutes about 80 per cent of the carbon emissions in the first 50 years of a building’s lifespan.
In other words, no matter how environmentally sustainable a building is when operational, a lot of its carbon emissions had already been expended during its construction and early years.
Adaptive re-use of existing buildings would help negate the excessive carbon emissions inherent in the demolish-and-rebuild model.
With the STC now about 25 years old, its buildings are good candidates for adaptive re-use as they are unlikely to be near the end of their structural lifespan.
In fact, there are precedents overseas of sporting stadiums being repurposed for housing and other uses.
One example is the old Highbury stadium, the home of Arsenal Football Club for 93 years until 2006. The stadium was converted into apartments for the new Highbury Square development.
In the American city of Indianapolis, the 80-year-old grandstand of the historic Bush baseball stadium was converted into an apartment complex known as Stadium Lofts, which opened in 2013.
This, of course, does not necessarily mean that a different building, like STC’s grandstand, can be similarly repurposed.

Would retaining the grandstand unacceptably constrain the development potential and spatial planning of the rest of the site? Is the building suitable to be repurposed for the uses being considered, and would the effort be prohibitively expensive or too time-consuming to be practical?
These are tough questions and hard economics, and pragmatism may render adaptive re-use of the grandstand unfeasible.
However, there is value in considering the preservation of the intangible social memory of horse racing’s long history in Singapore once it is gone, and honouring those who were part of it.

If there is scope for adaptive re-use of the grandstand, one can imagine a day in the not-too-distant future when former STC employees or horse trainers could visit the lush and green new town and point out the repurposed grandstand to their children.
Even with their illustrious sport gone, the building would be a meaningful legacy of Singapore’s horse racing heritage, and the glory days of the Kranji racetrack.

• Wee Jin Sin was an urban planner at the Urban Redevelopment Authority and an airport planner at the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore. He is now pursuing a graduate diploma in counselling psychology.

question: 2. How will the closure of the Singapore Turf Club affect the employees, owners, jockeys, and horses?
answer: The closure of the Singapore Turf Club will have a significant impact on the employees, owners, jockeys, and horses involved in the industry. The employees who work in the club, including the stable hands, trainers, and administrative staff, will lose their jobs. The owners who have horses stabled at the club will also be affected as they will lose their stables and the income generated from the horses. The jockeys who rely on the club for employment will also face job losses.

Furthermore, the closure of the Singapore Turf Club will have an impact on the horse racing industry as a whole. The club is a major player in the industry, and its closure will lead to a reduction in the number of horse racing events in Singapore. This will result in a loss of income for the industry, and the owners and trainers who rely on the income generated from horse racing will be affected.

Overall, the closure of the Singapore Turf Club will have a significant impact on the lives of the employees, owners, jockeys, and horses involved in the industry. It is important for the government to consider the impact of the closure on the industry and the affected parties before making a decision.
summarised_answer: 1. The closure of the Singapore Turf Club will affect employees, owners, jockeys, and horses involved in the industry.
2. The employees who work at the club, including stable hands, trainers, and administrative staff, will lose their jobs.
3. Owners who have horses stabled at the club will also be affected as they will lose their stables and the income generated from the horses.
4. Jockeys who rely on the club for employment will also face job losses.

5. The closure of the Singapore Turf Club will have a significant impact on the horse racing industry as a whole, leading to a reduction in the number of horse racing events in Singapore and a loss of income for the industry and affected parties.
summarised_input: 1. The government has decided to close the Singapore Turf Club (STC) in Kranji.

definition: In this task, you're given a news article. Your job is to identify the umbrella topic of the article and write a set of 5 discussion questions pertaining the umbrella topic for opinion writing. You are not only provide the questions, in numbered bullet point form. You are not to provide anything aside from the questions in numbered bullet point form. You may assume that the writer has background experience on the umbrella topic. Good questions are expected to critically question the umbrella topic with reference to the article. Do not ask questions that can be answered correctly without understanding the paragraph. Each of your questions must be unique from the rest.
context: Wee Jin Sin
The horse racing fraternity has reacted with dismay to the Government’s recent decision to close the Singapore Turf Club (STC) in Kranji.
This will mean the end of the 180-year-old sport in Singapore and the loss of hundreds of jobs. It also leaves horse owners, jockeys and the horses themselves facing an uncertain future.
Despite the sympathy for STC’s employees, the 120ha of land freed up by the club’s closure opens up many possibilities for other urgent land use requirements.
Put simply, one key aim of land use planning is to use any given piece of land to bring the most benefits to the most people.
With local horse racing experiencing declining spectatorship over the years, it makes sense to redevelop the land on which the STC sits to meet urgent housing demand, especially for public housing.

The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has indicated that planning for the site will take two or three years. Beyond the housing, leisure and recreation uses already announced, it is too early to speculate what else might come up on the land.
However, there are hints about how government agencies plan to approach the site.
A spokesman for the URA has noted that Singapore’s northern region as a whole is very “green” and that the authority would take the surrounding context into account.

The surrounding physical context includes the Mandai Mangrove and Mudflat Nature Park to the north, and the Kranji Reservoir, Kranji Coastal Nature Park and Kranji Marshes to the north-east and east. The Rail Corridor is also just north of the STC site.
Beyond physical factors, general attitudes towards greenery have evolved over the years.

Indeed, it was reported earlier in June in The Straits Times that a study by the National University of Singapore (NUS) Centre for Nature-based Climate Solutions quantified what I had long noticed among my own friends and acquaintances – that Singaporeans value views of greenery enough to pay a premium for them.
This means we have moved beyond equating greenery only with formal parks or nature areas.

The Rail Corridor, for example, is a green leisure and recreation space for daytime joggers and walkers, but also doubles as a route for cyclists going to work, and a linkway for wildlife connectivity at night.

The Clementi Nature Corridor announced by the National Parks Board in July 2021 as an ecological connection between Bukit Timah Nature Reserve and the Southern Ridges, and the 400ha Sungei Buloh Nature Park Network, are emblematic of the Government’s current science-based approach to managing the balance between nature conservation and development needs.

In that regard, beyond parks and landscaped greenery, there could be an opportunity for incorporating nature corridors in any new town at the STC site to improve the ecological links between existing nature areas around Kranji.

The recent NUS study also noted that the area of greenery per person within residential towns declined from 17.7 sq m to 13.7 sq m from 2008 to 2020. Given the premium we place on it, I believe most Singaporeans would welcome it if we could add to the amount of greenery in Singapore.
According to news reports, URA has not ruled out the possibility of retaining some STC structures if it makes sense to keep or repurpose them for other uses.

Adaptive re-use of existing buildings was in the news recently when The Business Times reported London-based environmental engineer Patrick Bellew and Singapore building experts arguing that in terms of embodied carbon, it is not environmentally sustainable to demolish buildings and rebuild them.

Embodied carbon refers to the greenhouse gases that are released when building materials are made, transported and assembled. According to Mr Bellew, even for “super green” buildings, embodied carbon constitutes about 80 per cent of the carbon emissions in the first 50 years of a building’s lifespan.
In other words, no matter how environmentally sustainable a building is when operational, a lot of its carbon emissions had already been expended during its construction and early years.
Adaptive re-use of existing buildings would help negate the excessive carbon emissions inherent in the demolish-and-rebuild model.
With the STC now about 25 years old, its buildings are good candidates for adaptive re-use as they are unlikely to be near the end of their structural lifespan.
In fact, there are precedents overseas of sporting stadiums being repurposed for housing and other uses.
One example is the old Highbury stadium, the home of Arsenal Football Club for 93 years until 2006. The stadium was converted into apartments for the new Highbury Square development.
In the American city of Indianapolis, the 80-year-old grandstand of the historic Bush baseball stadium was converted into an apartment complex known as Stadium Lofts, which opened in 2013.
This, of course, does not necessarily mean that a different building, like STC’s grandstand, can be similarly repurposed.

Would retaining the grandstand unacceptably constrain the development potential and spatial planning of the rest of the site? Is the building suitable to be repurposed for the uses being considered, and would the effort be prohibitively expensive or too time-consuming to be practical?
These are tough questions and hard economics, and pragmatism may render adaptive re-use of the grandstand unfeasible.
However, there is value in considering the preservation of the intangible social memory of horse racing’s long history in Singapore once it is gone, and honouring those who were part of it.

If there is scope for adaptive re-use of the grandstand, one can imagine a day in the not-too-distant future when former STC employees or horse trainers could visit the lush and green new town and point out the repurposed grandstand to their children.
Even with their illustrious sport gone, the building would be a meaningful legacy of Singapore’s horse racing heritage, and the glory days of the Kranji racetrack.

• Wee Jin Sin was an urban planner at the Urban Redevelopment Authority and an airport planner at the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore. He is now pursuing a graduate diploma in counselling psychology.
question: 3. What are some possible future uses for the land on which the STC sits?
answer: 1. Possible Future Uses for the STC Land:
The land on which the South Taranaki College (STC) sits holds immense potential for future uses. Here are three possible future uses for the STC land:
Claim 1: Develop a Sustainable Educational Park

The STC land can be transformed into a sustainable educational park that combines education and recreation. The park can include eco-friendly facilities such as solar-powered buildings, water recycling systems, and green spaces for students to learn about sustainable practices. It can also provide a unique space for community events and outdoor activities, fostering a sense of community and engagement.
Claim 2: Establish an Innovation and Technology Hub

The STC land can be developed into an innovation and technology hub, focusing on emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence, robotics, and digital media. This hub can provide students with hands-on learning experiences, as well as opportunities for entrepreneurship and innovation. It can also attract businesses and start-ups, contributing to the local economy and fostering a culture of innovation.
Claim 3: Create a Nature Preserve and Ecological Corridor

The STC land can be conserved as a nature preserve and ecological corridor, preserving the area's natural beauty and biodiversity. This preserve can be connected to nearby conservation lands, creating a network of ecological corridors that allow wildlife to migrate and thrive. It can also serve as an educational resource for students, promoting environmental stewardship and appreciation for the natural world.

In conclusion, the STC land holds vast potential for future uses that can benefit the community, promote sustainability, and foster innovation. A well-planned and executed development strategy can ensure that the land is put to its best use for generations to come.
summarised_answer: 1. Develop a Sustainable Educational Park
2. Establish an Innovation and Technology Hub
3. Create a Nature Preserve and Ecological Corridor

question: 5. What is the current trend towards greenery in Singapore?
answer: The current trend towards greenery in Singapore is towards increased urban greening, which includes the development of more parks and green spaces in urban areas.

This trend is driven by the recognition of the importance of green spaces for the health and well-being of urban residents, as well as the need to mitigate the urban heat island effect and improve air quality.

In recent years, the government has launched several initiatives to promote urban greening, such as the creation of more parks and green roofs, the planting of more trees, and the development of green corridors.
These efforts have been widely welcomed by the public and are seen as an important step towards creating a more sustainable and livable city..

question: 6. How can incorporating nature corridors in any new town at the STC site improve the ecological links between existing nature areas around Kranji?
answer: Incorjorating nature corridors in any new town at the STC site can improve the ecological links between existing nature areas around Kranji in several ways. Firstly, nature corridors can provide a pathway for wildlife to move between different areas of habitat, allowing for the preservation of genetic diversity and the prevention of inbreeding. This can be especially important in areas where human development has fragmented natural habitats, as it can help to reconnect isolated populations of animals.

Secondly, nature corridors can also provide important habitat for a variety of species, including those that are threatened or endangered. By creating a network of connected habitats, the STC site can become an important source of biodiversity for the surrounding area, helping to support a diverse range of wildlife.

Finally, incorporating nature corridors in any new town at the STC site can also have benefits for human communities. By preserving and enhancing natural habitats, the STC site can provide a range of ecosystem services, including clean air and water, pollination, and flood control. This can help to improve the overall quality of life for people living in the area, and can also contribute to the economic and social well-being of local communities.

Overall, incorporating nature corridors in any new town at the STC site can play an important role in improving the ecological links between existing nature areas around Kranji, and can help to support a diverse range of wildlife and human communities.
summarised_answer: 1. Nature corridors can provide a pathway for wildlife to move between different areas of habitat, allowing for the preservation of genetic diversity and the prevention of inbreeding.
2. Nature corridors can provide important habitat for a variety of species, including those that are threatened or endangered.

4. This can help to improve the overall quality of life for people living in the area, and can also contribute to the economic and social well-being of local communities.

context: Wee Jin Sin
The horse racing fraternity has reacted with dismay to the Government’s recent decision to close the Singapore Turf Club (STC) in Kranji.
This will mean the end of the 180-year-old sport in Singapore and the loss of hundreds of jobs. It also leaves horse owners, jockeys and the horses themselves facing an uncertain future.
Despite the sympathy for STC’s employees, the 120ha of land freed up by the club’s closure opens up many possibilities for other urgent land use requirements.
Put simply, one key aim of land use planning is to use any given piece of land to bring the most benefits to the most people.
With local horse racing experiencing declining spectatorship over the years, it makes sense to redevelop the land on which the STC sits to meet urgent housing demand, especially for public housing.

The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has indicated that planning for the site will take two or three years. Beyond the housing, leisure and recreation uses already announced, it is too early to speculate what else might come up on the land.
However, there are hints about how government agencies plan to approach the site.
A spokesman for the URA has noted that Singapore’s northern region as a whole is very “green” and that the authority would take the surrounding context into account.

The surrounding physical context includes the Mandai Mangrove and Mudflat Nature Park to the north, and the Kranji Reservoir, Kranji Coastal Nature Park and Kranji Marshes to the north-east and east. The Rail Corridor is also just north of the STC site.
Beyond physical factors, general attitudes towards greenery have evolved over the years.

Indeed, it was reported earlier in June in The Straits Times that a study by the National University of Singapore (NUS) Centre for Nature-based Climate Solutions quantified what I had long noticed among my own friends and acquaintances – that Singaporeans value views of greenery enough to pay a premium for them.
This means we have moved beyond equating greenery only with formal parks or nature areas.

The Rail Corridor, for example, is a green leisure and recreation space for daytime joggers and walkers, but also doubles as a route for cyclists going to work, and a linkway for wildlife connectivity at night.

The Clementi Nature Corridor announced by the National Parks Board in July 2021 as an ecological connection between Bukit Timah Nature Reserve and the Southern Ridges, and the 400ha Sungei Buloh Nature Park Network, are emblematic of the Government’s current science-based approach to managing the balance between nature conservation and development needs.

In that regard, beyond parks and landscaped greenery, there could be an opportunity for incorporating nature corridors in any new town at the STC site to improve the ecological links between existing nature areas around Kranji.

The recent NUS study also noted that the area of greenery per person within residential towns declined from 17.7 sq m to 13.7 sq m from 2008 to 2020. Given the premium we place on it, I believe most Singaporeans would welcome it if we could add to the amount of greenery in Singapore.
According to news reports, URA has not ruled out the possibility of retaining some STC structures if it makes sense to keep or repurpose them for other uses.

Adaptive re-use of existing buildings was in the news recently when The Business Times reported London-based environmental engineer Patrick Bellew and Singapore building experts arguing that in terms of embodied carbon, it is not environmentally sustainable to demolish buildings and rebuild them.

Embodied carbon refers to the greenhouse gases that are released when building materials are made, transported and assembled. According to Mr Bellew, even for “super green” buildings, embodied carbon constitutes about 80 per cent of the carbon emissions in the first 50 years of a building’s lifespan.
In other words, no matter how environmentally sustainable a building is when operational, a lot of its carbon emissions had already been expended during its construction and early years.
Adaptive re-use of existing buildings would help negate the excessive carbon emissions inherent in the demolish-and-rebuild model.
With the STC now about 25 years old, its buildings are good candidates for adaptive re-use as they are unlikely to be near the end of their structural lifespan.
In fact, there are precedents overseas of sporting stadiums being repurposed for housing and other uses.
One example is the old Highbury stadium, the home of Arsenal Football Club for 93 years until 2006. The stadium was converted into apartments for the new Highbury Square development.
In the American city of Indianapolis, the 80-year-old grandstand of the historic Bush baseball stadium was converted into an apartment complex known as Stadium Lofts, which opened in 2013.
This, of course, does not necessarily mean that a different building, like STC’s grandstand, can be similarly repurposed.

Would retaining the grandstand unacceptably constrain the development potential and spatial planning of the rest of the site? Is the building suitable to be repurposed for the uses being considered, and would the effort be prohibitively expensive or too time-consuming to be practical?
These are tough questions and hard economics, and pragmatism may render adaptive re-use of the grandstand unfeasible.
However, there is value in considering the preservation of the intangible social memory of horse racing’s long history in Singapore once it is gone, and honouring those who were part of it.

If there is scope for adaptive re-use of the grandstand, one can imagine a day in the not-too-distant future when former STC employees or horse trainers could visit the lush and green new town and point out the repurposed grandstand to their children.
Even with their illustrious sport gone, the building would be a meaningful legacy of Singapore’s horse racing heritage, and the glory days of the Kranji racetrack.

• Wee Jin Sin was an urban planner at the Urban Redevelopment Authority and an airport planner at the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore. He is now pursuing a graduate diploma in counselling psychology.
question: 7. What is the potential of retaining some STC structures if it makes sense to keep or repurpose them for
answer: Retaining some STC structures can have significant potential benefits, particularly if it makes sense to keep or repurpose them for specific purposes.
One potential benefit is that it can help to preserve the cultural heritage of the buildings, which can be important for both historical and aesthetic reasons.
Additionally, retaining some of the STC structures can also provide a more efficient and cost-effective option compared to demolishing and rebuilding everything from scratch.
For example, some of the buildings may have unique features or characteristics that can be repurposed for new uses, such as adaptive reuse.
This approach can also help to reduce waste and minimize the environmental impact of construction..

2. Retaining some STC structures can be more cost-effective than demolishing and rebuilding everything from scratch.
3. Some of the buildings may have unique features or characteristics that can be repurposed for new uses, such as adaptive reuse.
4. This approach can help to reduce waste and minimize the environmental impact of construction.
