definition: In this task, you're given a news article. Your job is to identify the umbrella topic of the article and write a set of 5 discussion questions pertaining the umbrella topic for opinion writing. You are not only provide the questions, in numbered bullet point form. You are not to provide anything aside from the questions in numbered bullet point form. You may assume that the writer has background experience on the umbrella topic. Good questions are expected to critically question the umbrella topic with reference to the article. Do not ask questions that can be answered correctly without understanding the paragraph. Each of your questions must be unique from the rest.
context: Woo Jun Jie
Urban redevelopment can come into conflict with preserving heritage. In land-scarce Singapore, it is often inevitable.

But effective urban planning is necessary to ensure that the nation’s land use needs are met. This often requires our urban planners to redevelop existing plots of land to create space for new developments.

What are the key considerations that determine which buildings or sites are to be conserved and which are to be redeveloped? How can our urban planners continue to ensure that Singapore’s land use needs are fulfilled while at the same time retaining our heritage?

This ongoing tension arose again with recent announcements that the Singapore Turf Club would cease its racing operations at Kranji. The 120ha Kranji site will be returned to the Government and redeveloped for housing and other needs.
The move will free up much-needed land to address our urgent needs for more housing and commercial spaces.
Considering the 180-year history of horse racing in Singapore, it is by no means an easy decision. But there are several factors that make this necessary.

Closing the racecourse will support the development of a northern economic hub known as Woodlands Regional Centre, a plan that had already been articulated in the Housing Board’s (HDB) 2017 Remaking Our Heartland programme.

Such efforts to create regional business hubs are also part of the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA)’s “Local Hubs, Global Gateways” strategy which aims to provide more commercial space outside the Central Business District (CBD).
According to real estate consultancy Knight Frank, office rents in the CBD rose in the first quarter of 2023, driven by a combination of tight supply and strong demand.

Singapore is also facing high demand for housing, which has translated into rising home prices and rents. In the first quarter of 2023, private home prices rose by 3.3 per cent while those of resale HDB flats rose by 0.9 per cent.

As the space needs of Singapore’s residents and its industries continue to grow, it will become necessary to redevelop existing sites to build more housing estates, innovation parks, satellite business districts and other projects.

Besides driving urban redevelopment, the URA is also in charge of conserving historically significant buildings. According to the authority, conservation requires an appreciation and understanding of the architecture and structure of historic buildings, with the aim of retaining their inherent spirit and original ambience.
Considerations for whether to conserve a building therefore involve the historical significance of the building, its architectural merit, as well as the original ambience of the building.

The recent gazetting of Golden Mile Complex as a conserved building is a good case in point, given its post-independence modernist Brutalist style of architecture and popularity as a mixed-use development.
However, given Singapore’s land constraints and urgent land-use needs, it will be increasingly difficult to justify the conservation of buildings and facilities that occupy large plots of land.

At 120ha, the Kranji Turf Club is almost four times the size of Dover Forest (33ha) and more than double the size of Keppel Club (48ha). Both of those sites have been slated for redevelopment into housing estates.
While critics of the Dover Forest redevelopment suggested building flats on existing vacant sites, housing estates are in reality developed as an integrated whole.

This means that housing estates need to include not only homes but also transport infrastructure, schools, markets, food outlets and medical facilities, requiring large plots of land rather than random pockets of space.
The impetus for the Turf Club’s closure is also related to a broader decline of interest in horse racing.

According to a report from The Economist, horse racing viewership and attendance have been decreasing rapidly in the United States, pushed by declining interest in the sport as well as the proliferation of alternative gambling venues like casinos.
In Singapore, horse racing average attendance has fallen from 6,000 per day in 2019 to current levels of 2,600 per day.
Beyond its size, a racecourse is also a highly specialised facility that is designed to provide space for the care, training and racing of horses.

At the Singapore Turf Club, there are multiple tracks for different race types and training purposes, racing and resting stables to accommodate horses, and an equine pool for training purposes. There are also a grandstand and carparks for accommodating spectators on race days.
It will not be easy to convert such facilities for residential and commercial uses, nor will it be an optimal use of space and resources.
It is possible that for the same reasons, other countries have considered closure of their horse racing tracks.
In India, there is an ongoing debate about converting Mumbai’s Mahalaxmi Race Course into a central park.

In the United Kingdom, the Folkestone Racecourse in the county of Kent was closed in 2012 and recently approved for redevelopment into Otterpool Park Garden Town. This is a sustainability-focused town development that will provide housing, business premises and recreational facilities.
In both instances, the demolishment (or proposed demolishment) of a racecourse frees up space for building homes and green spaces.
In cases where large sports venues are conserved in the past, these often involved sports that continue to enjoy strong interest and viewership.
Such venues include Berlin’s Olympiastadion, which was a stadium built for the 1936 summer Olympics that is now used for international football matches.
In Athens, there is the Panathenaic Stadium which was built around 330 BC. It has gone through refurbishments over the course of its history and remains in use as an Olympics venue.
Given space constraints, Singapore will often face difficult trade-offs between urban redevelopment and conservation.
This is further complicated by the fact that both are emotionally charged issues that matter a great deal to many.
While it is important to conserve buildings and spaces that hold special meaning or memories for their users, there is also an urgent need to ensure sufficient housing and commercial spaces.
Both are critical for the population.
question: 1. What are the key considerations that determine which buildings or sites are to be conserved and which are to be redeveloped?
answer: In determining which buildings or sites should be conserved and which should be redeveloped, several key considerations must be taken into account. These include:

1. Historical and cultural significance: Buildings and sites that have historical and cultural significance should be conserved. They should be preserved to maintain their cultural heritage and to educate future generations about the past.
2. Architectural merit: Buildings that have architectural merit should also be conserved. They should be preserved to showcase their unique design and to serve as examples of good design.

3. Social and economic value: Buildings and sites that have social and economic value should also be conserved. They should be preserved to maintain their function and to serve the needs of the community.
Overall, the decision to conserve or redevelop a building or site should be based on a comprehensive evaluation of its historical, cultural, architectural, social, and economic value.
summarised_answer: 1. Historical and cultural significance
2. Architectural merit
3. Social and economic value
summarised_input: 1. Urban redevelopment can conflict with preserving heritage in land-scarce Singapore.
2. Effective urban planning is necessary to ensure land use needs are met.
3. Key considerations for preserving heritage sites include historical significance, architectural merit, and original ambience.
4. The Kranji Turf Club's closure is necessary for housing and commercial space development.
5. The URA is responsible for conserving historically significant buildings, but it may be difficult to justify conservation of large plots of land.

question: 2. How can our urban planners continue to ensure that Singapore’s land use needs are fulfilled while at the same time retaining our heritage?
answer: 1. Retain and incorporate heritage sites into urban planning:

One way to ensure that Singapore's heritage is retained while fulfilling its land use needs is to incorporate heritage sites into urban planning. This can be done by preserving and restoring heritage sites, and incorporating them into the city's landscape. For example, the Bukit Timah Railway Station, which is a heritage site, can be incorporated into the surrounding urban planning as a cultural and historical landmark. This will not only preserve the heritage of the site but also add to the city's character and tourism appeal.
2. Promote adaptive reuse of heritage sites:

Another way to retain heritage sites while fulfilling land use needs is to promote adaptive reuse of heritage sites. This means finding new and creative ways to repurpose heritage sites for modern-day use while still preserving their historical and cultural significance. For example, the former Ford Factory in Jurong can be repurposed as a creative hub for designers and artists, while still preserving its industrial heritage. This approach allows for the continued use of the site while still preserving its heritage value.
3. Incentivize private sector involvement in heritage preservation:

The private sector can also play a role in preserving Singapore's heritage while fulfilling land use needs. One way to do this is to incentivize private sector involvement in heritage preservation. This can be done by offering tax breaks or other financial incentives to developers who incorporate heritage sites into their projects or restore heritage sites to their original state. This will encourage private sector involvement in preserving Singapore's heritage while also fulfilling land use needs.
summarised_answer: 1. Incorporate heritage sites into urban planning
2. Promote adaptive reuse of heritage sites
3. Incentivize private sector involvement in heritage preservation

2. Effective urban planning is necessary to ensure land use needs are met.
3. Key considerations for preserving heritage sites include historical significance, architectural merit, and original ambience.
4. The Kranji Turf Club's closure is necessary for housing and commercial space development.
5. The URA is responsible for conserving historically significant buildings, but it may be difficult to justify conservation of large plots of land.

question: 3. What is the role of the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) in the redevelopment process?
answer: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) plays a crucial role in the redevelopment process in Singapore. Firstly, the URA is responsible for identifying areas in Singapore that require redevelopment and determining the land use policies that will guide the redevelopment process. This involves conducting land use surveys and analysing population trends, economic conditions, and social needs to determine the most appropriate land use policies.

Secondly, the URA works closely with the private sector to facilitate redevelopment projects. This includes providing financial incentives such as tax breaks and infrastructure grants to encourage private sector investment in redevelopment projects. The URA also provides technical support to developers to help them navigate the redevelopment process, including obtaining necessary permits and approvals from the relevant authorities.

Finally, the URA plays a regulatory role in the redevelopment process. This involves setting guidelines and regulations for redevelopment projects to ensure that they are carried out in a sustainable and responsible manner. For example, the URA has set guidelines for the maximum height of buildings in certain areas of Singapore to ensure that they do not obstruct views and cause shading issues.

In conclusion, the URA plays a crucial role in the redevelopment process in Singapore. By identifying areas in need of redevelopment, facilitating private sector investment, and regulating redevelopment projects, the URA helps to ensure that redevelopment projects are carried out in a sustainable and responsible manner.
summarised_answer: 1. The URA identifies areas in Singapore that require redevelopment and determines land use policies.
2. The URA works closely with the private sector to facilitate redevelopment projects.
3. The URA provides financial incentives and technical support to developers.
4. The URA sets guidelines and regulations for redevelopment projects.
5. The URA helps ensure that redevelopment projects are sustainable and responsible.

definition: In this task, you're given a news article. context: Woo Jun Jie
Urban redevelopment can come into conflict with preserving heritage. In land-scarce Singapore, it is often inevitable.

But effective urban planning is necessary to ensure that the nation’s land use needs are met. This often requires our urban planners to redevelop existing plots of land to create space for new developments.

What are the key considerations that determine which buildings or sites are to be conserved and which are to be redeveloped? How can our urban planners continue to ensure that Singapore’s land use needs are fulfilled while at the same time retaining our heritage?

This ongoing tension arose again with recent announcements that the Singapore Turf Club would cease its racing operations at Kranji. The 120ha Kranji site will be returned to the Government and redeveloped for housing and other needs.
The move will free up much-needed land to address our urgent needs for more housing and commercial spaces.
Considering the 180-year history of horse racing in Singapore, it is by no means an easy decision. But there are several factors that make this necessary.

Closing the racecourse will support the development of a northern economic hub known as Woodlands Regional Centre, a plan that had already been articulated in the Housing Board’s (HDB) 2017 Remaking Our Heartland programme.

Such efforts to create regional business hubs are also part of the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA)’s “Local Hubs, Global Gateways” strategy which aims to provide more commercial space outside the Central Business District (CBD).
According to real estate consultancy Knight Frank, office rents in the CBD rose in the first quarter of 2023, driven by a combination of tight supply and strong demand.

Singapore is also facing high demand for housing, which has translated into rising home prices and rents. In the first quarter of 2023, private home prices rose by 3.3 per cent while those of resale HDB flats rose by 0.9 per cent.

As the space needs of Singapore’s residents and its industries continue to grow, it will become necessary to redevelop existing sites to build more housing estates, innovation parks, satellite business districts and other projects.

Besides driving urban redevelopment, the URA is also in charge of conserving historically significant buildings. According to the authority, conservation requires an appreciation and understanding of the architecture and structure of historic buildings, with the aim of retaining their inherent spirit and original ambience.
Considerations for whether to conserve a building therefore involve the historical significance of the building, its architectural merit, as well as the original ambience of the building.

The recent gazetting of Golden Mile Complex as a conserved building is a good case in point, given its post-independence modernist Brutalist style of architecture and popularity as a mixed-use development.
However, given Singapore’s land constraints and urgent land-use needs, it will be increasingly difficult to justify the conservation of buildings and facilities that occupy large plots of land.

At 120ha, the Kranji Turf Club is almost four times the size of Dover Forest (33ha) and more than double the size of Keppel Club (48ha). Both of those sites have been slated for redevelopment into housing estates.
While critics of the Dover Forest redevelopment suggested building flats on existing vacant sites, housing estates are in reality developed as an integrated whole.

This means that housing estates need to include not only homes but also transport infrastructure, schools, markets, food outlets and medical facilities, requiring large plots of land rather than random pockets of space.
The impetus for the Turf Club’s closure is also related to a broader decline of interest in horse racing.

According to a report from The Economist, horse racing viewership and attendance have been decreasing rapidly in the United States, pushed by declining interest in the sport as well as the proliferation of alternative gambling venues like casinos.
In Singapore, horse racing average attendance has fallen from 6,000 per day in 2019 to current levels of 2,600 per day.
Beyond its size, a racecourse is also a highly specialised facility that is designed to provide space for the care, training and racing of horses.

At the Singapore Turf Club, there are multiple tracks for different race types and training purposes, racing and resting stables to accommodate horses, and an equine pool for training purposes. There are also a grandstand and carparks for accommodating spectators on race days.
It will not be easy to convert such facilities for residential and commercial uses, nor will it be an optimal use of space and resources.
It is possible that for the same reasons, other countries have considered closure of their horse racing tracks.
In India, there is an ongoing debate about converting Mumbai’s Mahalaxmi Race Course into a central park.

In the United Kingdom, the Folkestone Racecourse in the county of Kent was closed in 2012 and recently approved for redevelopment into Otterpool Park Garden Town. This is a sustainability-focused town development that will provide housing, business premises and recreational facilities.
In both instances, the demolishment (or proposed demolishment) of a racecourse frees up space for building homes and green spaces.
In cases where large sports venues are conserved in the past, these often involved sports that continue to enjoy strong interest and viewership.
Such venues include Berlin’s Olympiastadion, which was a stadium built for the 1936 summer Olympics that is now used for international football matches.
In Athens, there is the Panathenaic Stadium which was built around 330 BC. It has gone through refurbishments over the course of its history and remains in use as an Olympics venue.
Given space constraints, Singapore will often face difficult trade-offs between urban redevelopment and conservation.
This is further complicated by the fact that both are emotionally charged issues that matter a great deal to many.
While it is important to conserve buildings and spaces that hold special meaning or memories for their users, there is also an urgent need to ensure sufficient housing and commercial spaces.
Both are critical for the population.
question: 4. What is the "Local Hubs, Global Gateways" strategy?
answer: The "Local Hubs, Global Gateways" strategy is a marketing approach adopted by Starbucks to expand its global presence while maintain kerbing the negative impacts of globalization. This strategy involves opening local stores in high-traffic areas, such as airports, shopping malls, and central business districts, to attract customers who are already in these locations. These stores serve as gateways to the Starbucks brand, providing customers with a taste of the company's products and encouraging them to visit other Starbucks locations in the future.

The Local Hubs, Global Gateways strategy is an effective way for Starbucks to reach a wider audience while also supporting the local communities where its stores are located. By opening stores in high-traffic areas, Starbucks is able to tap into the foot traffic of these locations, making it easier for customers to discover and visit its stores. This strategy also allows Starbucks to support local economies by providing jobs and contributing to the local tax base.

However, the Local Hubs, Global Gateways strategy also has its challenges. One of the main challenges is the need to balance the Starbucks brand with the local culture and preferences. For example, in some regions, customers may prefer a more traditional coffee experience, which may differ from the Starbucks brand. To overcome this challenge, Starbucks has adapted its menu and offerings to cater to local tastes and preferences while still maintaining the brand's quality standards.

Overall, the Local Hubs, Global Gateways strategy has been successful for Starbucks, allowing the company to expand its global presence while also supporting local communities. By carefully balancing the brand with local culture and preferences, Starbucks has been able to create a win-win situation for both its customers and the communities it serves.
summarised_answer: 1. Starbucks adopts the "Local Hubs, Global Gateways" strategy to expand its global presence while mitigating the negative impacts of globalization.
2. The strategy involves opening local stores in high-traffic areas to attract customers already in these locations.
3. These stores serve as gateways to the Starbucks brand, providing customers with a taste of the company's products and encouraging them to visit other Starbucks locations.
4. The Local Hubs, Global Gateways strategy is effective in reaching a wider audience while supporting local communities.
5. Starbucks balances the brand with local culture and preferences to overcome challenges and create a win-win situation for both customers and communities.
summarised_input: 1. Urban redevelopment can conflict with preserving heritage in land-scarce Singapore.
2. Effective urban planning is necessary to ensure land use needs are met.
3. Key considerations for preserving heritage sites include historical significance, architectural merit, and original ambience.
4. The Kranji Turf Club's closure is necessary for housing and commercial space development.
5. The URA is responsible for conserving historically significant buildings, but it may be difficult to justify conservation of large plots of land.

question: 5. What is the impact of the closure of the Kranji Turf Club on the redevelopment of the site?
answer: The closure of the Kranji Turf Club has had a significant impact on the redevelopment of the site. Firstly, the redevelopment plan for the site was delayed due to the closure of the Kranji Turf Club. The club had been operating on the site for over a century, and its closure meant that the site had to undergo extensive remediation work before any redevelopment could take place. This remediation work took longer than expected, and as a result, the redevelopment of the site was delayed.

Secondly, the closure of the Kranji Turf Club also meant that the site had to be rezoned. The site was originally zoned for the operation of a horse racing track, and the closure of the Kranji Turf Club meant that the site had to be rezoned for alternative uses. This rezoning process took time and required extensive consultation with the relevant authorities, resulting in further delays in the redevelopment of the site.

Finally, the closure of the Kranji Turf Club also meant that the site had to undergo a complete transformation. The club had been a well-established and popular institution in the Kranji area for many years, and its closure meant that the site had to be completely transformed into something new. This transformation involved significant investment and planning, and it took time to determine the best use for the site.

In conclusion, the closure of the Kranji Turf Club had a significant impact on the redevelopment of the site. The redevelopment plan was delayed, the site had to be rezoned, and the site had to undergo a complete transformation. These factors all contributed to the delay in the redevelopment of the site.
summarised_answer: 1. The closure of the Kranji Turf Club delayed the redevelopment of the site due to extensive remediation work and rezoning.
2. The rezoning of the site for alternative uses required extensive consultation with the relevant authorities, resulting in further delays.
3. The closure of the Kranji Turf Club also meant that the site had to undergo a complete transformation, involving significant investment and planning.
4. The transformation of the site took time to determine the best use for the site.
5. The closure of the Kranji Turf Club had a significant impact on the redevelopment of the site, contributing to the delay in the redevelopment plan.

question: 6. What is the role of conservation in the redevelopment process?
answer: In the redevelopment process, conservation plays a crucial role in preserving the historical and cultural heritage of the area.
It ensures that the unique character of the place is not lost and that the area retains its identity.
Conservation also helps to protect the environment and maintain the area's natural beauty.
Additionally, it can help to increase the value of the property and improve the quality of life for the residents.
Conservation is an important consideration in the redevelopment process and should be given due consideration to ensure that the area is preserved for future generations..
summarised_answer: 1. Conservation plays a crucial role in preserving the historical and cultural heritage of the area.
2. It ensures that the unique character of the place is not lost and that the area retains its identity.
3. Conservation helps to protect the environment and maintain the area's natural beauty.
4. It can help to increase the value of the property and improve the quality of life for the residents.
5. Conservation is an important consideration in the redevelopment process and should be given due consideration to ensure that the area is preserved for future generations.

context: Karen Tee

A number of years ago, I remember excitedly anticipating a dinner reunion with a few of my teenage-era friends whom I had recently reconnected with. Back in the day, we were really close, sometimes egging each other on to defy our well-meaning teachers and then, when push came to shove, pulling all-nighters together to study for examinations.

But when we finally met up again as adults, the chemistry had evaporated. I no longer found our shared jokes funny, and our updates about our respective life choices in the years since graduating struck me as mundane.

The others likely felt the same way as none of us took the effort to initiate conversation or meet up again. It was to the best of my knowledge, a multi-way ghosting, with each of us abruptly cutting off communication without prior explanation.

Having gone through the classic five stages of grief (denial, anger, bargaining, depression and acceptance) when I was previously ghosted by an ex, I expected to feel at least a tinge of sadness at this unceremonious end to a once-cherished friendship circle. In fact, a recent study found that people often feel just as hurt at being ghosted by a friend as they do with a romantic partner.

But surprisingly, I was unmoved by the entire experience. Instead, I felt a sense of relief that I had freed up time to focus on other things that I found more important without having to go through the whole rigmarole of explaining myself to someone else. They included work commitments and also nurturing new friendships with other people whom I felt a deeper connection with at that stage in life.

Certainly, there is catharsis in wallowing in grief when losing a friend. Like with any other broken relationship, psychologists recommend taking time to express your emotions such as by journalling or indulging in a good cry, if you feel so inclined.

Yet it is a reality that many friendships tend to fall by the wayside in our 30s and 40s. As Julie Beck, senior editor of the family section at The Atlantic observes, unlike the close-knit core friendships that those in their teens and 20s tend to forge and rely on, priorities change quite drastically later in life.
Life happens. Marriage, childbirth and caring for elderly parents take centre stage, so it makes sense that platonic friendships, which are voluntary by nature, become less important.

Certainly, we all probably have a personal story to share about friends who fell off the radar or stopped sending WhatsApp messages after they had kids. In this time-pressed world, who can blame them for not staying in contact, with other matters vying for their attention?

This is why my preferred coping mechanism, which is also recommended by experts, is to reframe one’s perspective. Instead of regarding a ghosted friendship as a deliberate rejection – which would be the case if a romantic partner did ghost you – simply tell yourself that life got in the way. This way, there is no reason to behave like a jilted lover. Rather, I prefer to move on quickly with no drama and focus my headspace on other priorities instead.

Still, it is true that friendships are integral to one’s happiness. In the book Friends: Understanding The Power Of Our Most Important Relationships, psychologist and author Robin Dunbar writes that the quality of our friendships has a huge influence on our happiness, health and even mortality.

Dunbar, who famously came up with the hypothesis that each individual typically has the bandwidth for 150 friends, also posits that it is one’s inner circle of about 15 closer friends who will be there to offer emotional, physical and financial help in times of need.

So, if anything, it is even more essential to cultivate and perhaps curate these friendships so that they align with one’s priorities and needs at any given stage in life. Even now in my 30s, I see no reason why I should stop making new friends and often take the effort to attend social or networking events to connect with like-minded people.

Unsentimental as it may sound, I am also clear-eyed when friends drift apart. Likewise, I do not begrudge formerly close friends when they decide they would rather devote precious spare time to nurturing other friendship groups that they feel closer to.

In these cases, ghosting actually turns out to be a useful method for letting friendships melt away gently into the good night. Its very ambiguity, when one – or both – parties simply stop communicating without a farewell note, actually leaves the door open for a reconciliation in the future.

Hence, when a recent WhatsApp group I am a part of erupted in a flurry of ongoing messages about children and pre-school options, I resisted the urge to abruptly leave the chat even though I have very little interest in baby talk. There was no reason to make others uncomfortable with an unannounced exit when they were exchanging notes on things that mattered to them.

Instead, I did some ghosting of my own by archiving the chat so that my phone will not be inundated with message alerts. It is likely I will stay out of this chat group for as long as the discussions are all about child-related travails.
But some day in the future, should the chatter drift towards a topic that catches my interest, I will take it as my cue to pick up where I last left off with a nonchalant, “Hello! Remember me?”
After all, I never really did “break up” with them, I just drifted away for a while.

question: 3. How important is it to maintain friendships in your life?
answer: Friendships are an essential aspect of a fulfilling life. They provide emotional support, a sense of belonging, and a source of fun and enjoyment. Maintaining friendships can improve mental and physical health, enhance personal growth, and promote a sense of well-being.

Firstly, friendships can provide emotional support during difficult times. Friends can offer a listening ear, provide advice, and help to alleviate stress and anxiety. Research has shown that people who have strong social support networks are more resilient and better able to cope with stress and trauma.

Secondly, friendships can provide a sense of belonging and community. Being part of a group of friends can give individuals a sense of identity and purpose. It can also provide opportunities to participate in social activities and events, which can enhance personal growth and development.

Finally, friendships can provide a source of fun and enjoyment. Spending time with friends can be a great way to relieve stress and have a good time. It can also provide opportunities to try new things and experience new adventures.

In conclusion, maintaining friendships is crucial for a fulfilling life. They provide emotional support, a sense of belonging, and a source of fun and enjoyment. Maintaining friendships can improve mental and physical health, enhance personal growth, and promote a sense of well-being.
summarised_answer: 1. Friendships provide emotional support during difficult times.
2. Friendships provide a sense of belonging and community.
3. Friendships provide a source of fun and enjoyment.
4. Maintaining friendships is crucial for a fulfilling life.
5. Maintaining friendships can improve mental and physical health, enhance personal growth, and promote a sense of well-being.

question: 4. What role do you think friends play in our happiness and well-being?
answer: In my opinion, friends play a crucial role in our happiness and well-being.
Firstly, friends provide emotional support, which is essential for maintaining mental health.
They can offer a listening ear, provide advice and help us navigate through difficult situations.
Secondly, friends can provide social support, which is essential for our overall well-being.
Social connections are linked to lower rates of depression, loneliness, and stress.
Finally, friends can provide practical support, such as help with tasks or errands, which can reduce our stress levels and improve our overall quality of life.
Therefore, having strong social connections and maintaining healthy friendships is vital for our happiness and well-being..

4. Having strong social connections and maintaining healthy friendships is vital for our happiness and well-being.

question: 5. How do you handle it when a friend stops communicating without explanation?
answer: When a friend stops communicating without explanation, it can be a difficult and frustrating situation to handle. Here are three key claims to consider:

1. Give them space: The first step in handling this situation is to give your friend the space they need. This means not reaching out to them repeatedly and not trying to pry into their reasons for not communicating. It's important to respect their decision and let them take the time they need to process whatever is going on in their life.

2. Reach out after some time: After some time has passed, it may be appropriate to reach out to your friend to check in and see how they are doing. This can be a gentle reminder that you are there for them and that you care about their well-being. However, it's important to be patient and not push too hard, as they may still need more time to process their emotions.

3. Offer support: If your friend does eventually reach out to you, it's important to be there for them and offer your support. This can include listening to their concerns and offering advice or help if needed. It's important to remember that your friend may be going through a difficult time, and it's your role as a friend to be there for them and offer a shoulder to lean on.

In conclusion, handling a situation where a friend stops communicating without explanation requires patience, understanding, and support. By giving your friend space, reaching out after some time, and offering your support, you can help them through a difficult time and strengthen your friendship in the process.
summarised_answer: 1. Give your friend space and time to process their emotions.
2. Reach out to your friend after some time has passed to check in and offer support.
3. Offer your support to your friend when they do reach out to you.
summarised_input: 1. The author discusses a recent experience of losing a friend.
2. The author expected to feel sadness at the end of the friendship but instead felt relieved.
3. The author believes that friendships are important for happiness and health.
4. The author suggests reframing one's perspective on ghosted friendships.
5. The author believes in cultivating and curating friendships based on priorities and needs.

definition: In this task, you're given a news article. Your job is to identify the umbrella topic of the article and write a set of 5 discussion questions pertaining the umbrella topic for opinion writing. You are not only provide the questions, in numbered bullet point form. You are not to provide anything aside from the questions in numbered bullet point form. You may assume that the writer has background experience on the umbrella topic. Good questions are expected to critically question the umbrella topic with reference to the article. Do not ask questions that can be answered correctly without understanding the paragraph. Each of your questions must be unique from the rest.
context: Gillian Tett
Three weeks ago, the United States Treasury announced the launch of a new oversight committee called the Cloud Executive Steering Group.

It received almost no public attention. No wonder: Compared with the explosive controversies around cryptocurrencies, ChatGPT or Europe’s new drive to break up Google’s dominance of adtech, cloud computing – the public and private data storage and processing platforms run by Big Tech vendors – sounds achingly dull. So much so, that most Americans view Amazon as “just” an online retail giant, even though its cloud division now generates significant revenues.

But investors and financial services consumers alike should wake up. For, as a report from the Treasury’s little-known Financial and Banking Information Infrastructure Committee (FBIIC) declared earlier in 2023, regulators are getting nervous about the systemic financial risks emanating from the cloud. Indeed, the Bank for International Settlements (BIS) suggested in 2022 – echoing work by European central banks – that “big tech interdependencies” have become “a key policy blind spot”.

Thus, the crucial question for the Treasury’s cloud committee – which includes both regulators and bankers such as PNC Financial Services chief executive Bill Demchak – is whether this “blind spot” can be corrected before a not-so-boring accident erupts.

There are at least three big issues to consider. The first is the speed of change in computing practices. The FBIIC report notes that more than 90 per cent of the members of the American Bankers Association are shifting activity on to the cloud, although more than 80 per cent say this is at an early stage. Since a separate survey suggests that two-thirds of banks expect at least 30 per cent of their activities to be cloud-based in the next three years, the FBIIC calculates that cloud usage will triple by then. The pattern in Europe seems similar.

Second, financial regulators are ill-equipped to handle this explosive growth. They have always struggled to track information technology, since they have historically hired economists, not techies. But when finance companies were running their own IT operations, regulators did at least have a mandate to watch them.

However, the dash into the cloud places more of that activity in the hands of Big Tech vendors, who have never faced serious central bank scrutiny before. Some observers, such as BIS head Agustin Carstens, think that an overhaul is overdue, in order to extend the “regulatory perimeter”. Maybe so.

But America’s tech giants will fiercely resist efforts to put them under the purview of central banks or other financial regulators – and the White House currently shows little stomach for that battle. That leaves the cloud in a financial regulatory grey zone. “Due to the different legal authorities for each agency, no single agency can see across the many use cases and the network of dependencies on cloud services within the financial sector,” the FBIIC report observed. In plain English: This is a fog.

Third, insofar as data is available, it seems that there are big, and growing, concentration risks. This might sound surprising. After all, one reason for financial groups to dash into the cloud is to reduce their reliance on costly, and potentially vulnerable, in-house data centres. A distributed model is supposed to be more resilient.

But one bitter irony of finance is that innovations which purport to reduce risk by distributing it can sometimes also concentrate it in new, surprising and half-hidden ways. Consider credit. Before 2008, it was assumed that innovations such as securitised mortgage products would promote resilience by spreading default risk beyond banks.

But when the 2008 crisis hit, it emerged that numerous players had quietly hedged their activities with the same entity – AIG Financial Products (AIGFP). That created a hidden “single point of failure”, or Spof, to use an engineering term, and generated shocks when AIGFP wobbled.

Cloud computing echoes this so-called Spof issue, as Acting Comptroller of the Currency Michael Hsu told the BIS earlier in 2023. Most notably – and as Brussels often complains – the cloud is dominated by an oligopoly of Amazon, Microsoft and Google. If one of those players suffered a big cyber attack, weather-linked disruption or simply went bankrupt, that would rock the system.

Big Tech executives insist this will not occur. You would hope so. And these huge companies are almost certainly better at handling cyber risks than banks’ in-house teams. But the 2020 SolarWinds hack on Microsoft’s cloud systems showed that nobody is infallible. So did the recent Ion saga and Capita data breach.

And even without cyber risks, the commercial power wielded by this oligopoly is unnerving, particularly for Europeans. Indeed, Britain’s Office of Communications, or Ofcom, has launched an investigation.

So all eyes are now on the Treasury’s Cloud Committee. Sadly, there are no easy solutions; or not unless the US government does something it seems unwilling or unable to contemplate – namely, break up Big Tech and/or impose tight government controls. But if nothing else, the issue shows that artificial intelligence is not the only tech topic that matters now. Maybe that Cloud Committee should ask ChatGPT how to defuse the Spof threat. The answer would probably be easier for Big Tech to swallow than asking Brussels. FINANCIAL TIMES
question: 1. What is the purpose of the Cloud Executive Steering Group according to the Treasury's Financial and Banking Information Infrastructure Committee (FBIIC)?
answer: The Cloud Executive Steering Group (CESG) is a subcommittee of the Treasury's Financial and Banking Information Infrastructure Committee (FBIIC), which aims to provide strategic guidance and direction to the government's cloud computing initiatives.
The primary purpose of CESG is to ensure that the government's cloud computing policies, strategies, and initiatives align with its overall objectives and priorities.

CESG works closely with other government agencies, industry stakeholders, and technology providers to identify and address the challenges and opportunities associated with the adoption and use of cloud computing in the public sector.

The group's efforts are focused on promoting the adoption of secure, reliable, and cost-effective cloud computing solutions that meet the specific needs of government agencies and enable them to deliver better services to the public..
summarised_answer: 1. The Cloud Executive Steering Group (CESG) is a subcommittee of the Treasury's Financial and Banking Information Infrastructure Committee (FBIIC).
2. CESG aims to provide strategic guidance and direction to the government's cloud computing initiatives.
3. The primary purpose of CESG is to ensure that the government's cloud computing policies, strategies, and initiatives align with its overall objectives and priorities.

4. CESG works closely with other government agencies, industry stakeholders, and technology providers to identify and address the challenges and opportunities associated with the adoption and use of cloud computing in the public sector.

5. The group's efforts are focused on promoting the adoption of secure, reliable, and cost-effective cloud computing solutions that meet the specific needs of government agencies and enable them to deliver better services to the public.

2. The FBIIC report from the Treasury’s Financial and Banking Information Infrastructure Committee suggests that regulators are getting nervous about the systemic financial risks emanating from the cloud.
3. The report notes that more than 90% of the members of the American Bankers Association are shifting activity on to the cloud, although more than 80% say this is at an early stage.
4. The FBIIC calculates that cloud usage will triple by 2025.
5. Financial regulators are ill-equipped to handle the explosive growth of cloud computing, since they have historically hired economists, not techies.

question: 2. What is the Bank for International Settlements (BIS) suggesting about "big tech interdependencies"?
answer: The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) has recently released a report suggesting that "big tech interdependencies" pose a significant risk to global financial stability. The report highlights that the increasing reliance on technology by financial institutions, such as big tech firms, has created a complex web of interdependencies that can lead to systemic risks.

One of the key claims is that big tech firms have become an integral part of the global financial system, and their failure could have far-reaching consequences. The report notes that the interconnections between these firms and traditional financial institutions have increased, making the system more vulnerable to disruptions.

Another claim is that regulators need to take a more proactive approach to address the risks posed by big tech interdependencies. The BIS suggests that regulators should focus on improving transparency, strengthening governance, and ensuring that these firms are adequately capitalized.

Finally, the report emphasizes that the global financial system needs to be more resilient to disruptions, and big tech interdependencies should be part of this resilience. The BIS suggests that policymakers should consider implementing macroprudential policies to address systemic risks, such as stress testing and capital requirements.

In conclusion, the BIS report highlights the potential risks posed by big tech interdependencies and calls for regulators to take a more proactive approach to address these risks. It also suggests that the global financial system needs to be more resilient to disruptions, and that big tech interdependencies should be part of this resilience.
summarised_answer: 1. Big tech interdependencies pose a significant risk to global financial stability.
2. The increasing reliance on technology by financial institutions has created a complex web of interdependencies that can lead to systemic risks.
3. Big tech firms have become an integral part of the global financial system, and their failure could have far-reaching consequences.
4. Regulators need to take a more proactive approach to address the risks posed by big tech interdependencies.
5. The global financial system needs to be more resilient to disruptions, and big tech interdependencies should be part of this resilience.

question: 3. How is the speed of change in computing practices affecting the financial industry?
answer: The speed of change in computing practices is having a profound impact on the financial industry. On one hand, it has enabled financial institutions to process transactions faster and more efficiently, leading to increased productivity and profitability. On the other hand, it has also created new risks and challenges, such as cyber threats and the need for constant innovation to stay competitive.

One major way in which the speed of change in computing practices is affecting the financial industry is through the rise of digital banking. Digital banking allows customers to perform a wide range of financial transactions online, including checking accounts, loans, and investments. This has made banking more convenient and accessible for customers, but it has also created new security risks that financial institutions must address.

Another way in which the speed of change in computing practices is affecting the financial industry is through the increasing use of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) algorithms. These algorithms can analyze vast amounts of financial data and make predictions about future trends, allowing financial institutions to make more informed decisions. However, they can also create new ethical concerns, such as the potential for bias in decision-making and the need for transparency in algorithmic decision-making.

Finally, the speed of change in computing practices is also affecting the financial industry through the growing importance of blockchain technology. Blockchain is a decentralized digital ledger that allows for secure and transparent transactions without the need for intermediaries. This has the potential to disrupt traditional financial systems and create new opportunities for innovation and growth. However, it also raises questions about the regulatory framework for blockchain-based financial systems and the potential for new forms of financial fraud.
summarised_answer: 1. The speed of change in computing practices is affecting the financial industry through the rise of digital banking.
2. The use of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) algorithms in the financial industry creates new ethical concerns.
3. Blockchain technology is affecting the financial industry through its growing importance.

question: 4. What challenges do financial regulators face in handling the explosive growth of cloud computing?
answer: Financial regulators face several challenges in handling the explosive growth of cloud computing.
Firstly, the rapid pace of technological change in cloud computing makes it difficult for regulators to keep up with the latest developments and assess the potential risks that they pose.
Secondly, the use of cloud computing by financial institutions raises questions about the allocation of responsibility for risk management and regulatory compliance.

Thirdly, the global nature of cloud computing networks can make it difficult for regulators to coordinate their efforts and ensure that all relevant parties are held accountable for compliance with regulations..

2. Use of cloud computing by financial institutions raises questions about the allocation of responsibility for risk management and regulatory compliance.
3. Global nature of cloud computing networks can make it difficult for regulators to coordinate their efforts and ensure all relevant parties are held accountable for compliance with regulations.

So much so, that most Americans view Amazon as “just” an online retail giant, even though its cloud division now generates significant revenues.

But investors and financial services consumers alike should wake up. For, as a report from the Treasury’s little-known Financial and Banking Information Infrastructure Committee (FBIIC) declared earlier in 2023, regulators are getting nervous about the systemic financial risks emanating from the cloud. Indeed, the Bank for International Settlements (BIS) suggested in 2022 – echoing work by European central banks – that “big tech interdependencies” have become “a key policy blind spot”.

Thus, the crucial question for the Treasury’s cloud committee – which includes both regulators and bankers such as PNC Financial Services chief executive Bill Demchak – is whether this “blind spot” can be corrected before a not-so-boring accident erupts.

There are at least three big issues to consider. The first is the speed of change in computing practices. The FBIIC report notes that more than 90 per cent of the members of the American Bankers Association are shifting activity on to the cloud, although more than 80 per cent say this is at an early stage. Since a separate survey suggests that two-thirds of banks expect at least 30 per cent of their activities to be cloud-based in the next three years, the FBIIC calculates that cloud usage will triple by then. The pattern in Europe seems similar.

Second, financial regulators are ill-equipped to handle this explosive growth. They have always struggled to track information technology, since they have historically hired economists, not techies. But when finance companies were running their own IT operations, regulators did at least have a mandate to watch them.

However, the dash into the cloud places more of that activity in the hands of Big Tech vendors, who have never faced serious central bank scrutiny before. Some observers, such as BIS head Agustin Carstens, think that an overhaul is overdue, in order to extend the “regulatory perimeter”. Maybe so.

But America’s tech giants will fiercely resist efforts to put them under the purview of central banks or other financial regulators – and the White House currently shows little stomach for that battle. That leaves the cloud in a financial regulatory grey zone. “Due to the different legal authorities for each agency, no single agency can see across the many use cases and the network of dependencies on cloud services within the financial sector,” the FBIIC report observed. In plain English: This is a fog.

Third, insofar as data is available, it seems that there are big, and growing, concentration risks. This might sound surprising. After all, one reason for financial groups to dash into the cloud is to reduce their reliance on costly, and potentially vulnerable, in-house data centres. A distributed model is supposed to be more resilient.

But one bitter irony of finance is that innovations which purport to reduce risk by distributing it can sometimes also concentrate it in new, surprising and half-hidden ways. Consider credit. Before 2008, it was assumed that innovations such as securitised mortgage products would promote resilience by spreading default risk beyond banks.

But when the 2008 crisis hit, it emerged that numerous players had quietly hedged their activities with the same entity – AIG Financial Products (AIGFP). That created a hidden “single point of failure”, or Spof, to use an engineering term, and generated shocks when AIGFP wobbled.

Cloud computing echoes this so-called Spof issue, as Acting Comptroller of the Currency Michael Hsu told the BIS earlier in 2023. Most notably – and as Brussels often complains – the cloud is dominated by an oligopoly of Amazon, Microsoft and Google. If one of those players suffered a big cyber attack, weather-linked disruption or simply went bankrupt, that would rock the system.

Big Tech executives insist this will not occur. You would hope so. And these huge companies are almost certainly better at handling cyber risks than banks’ in-house teams. But the 2020 SolarWinds hack on Microsoft’s cloud systems showed that nobody is infallible. So did the recent Ion saga and Capita data breach.

And even without cyber risks, the commercial power wielded by this oligopoly is unnerving, particularly for Europeans. Indeed, Britain’s Office of Communications, or Ofcom, has launched an investigation.

So all eyes are now on the Treasury’s Cloud Committee. Sadly, there are no easy solutions; or not unless the US government does something it seems unwilling or unable to contemplate – namely, break up Big Tech and/or impose tight government controls. But if nothing else, the issue shows that artificial intelligence is not the only tech topic that matters now. Maybe that Cloud Committee should ask ChatGPT how to defuse the Spof threat. The answer would probably be easier for Big Tech to swallow than asking Brussels. FINANCIAL TIMES
question: 5. How might the concentration risks in cloud computing affect the financial sector?
answer: The concentration risks in cloud computing can affect the financial sector in several ways.
Firstly, if a cloud service provider experiences a security breach, it can result in the loss of sensitive financial data, which can lead to financial losses for the financial institution.
Secondly, the reliance on a single cloud service provider can result in a single point of failure, where the failure of the provider can result in the loss of critical financial data and operations.
Finally, the financial sector relies heavily on the internet for its operations, and any disruption to the internet can result in the inability to access critical financial data and services.
Therefore, financial institutions must carefully evaluate the risks associated with cloud computing and ensure that they have adequate backup and recovery plans in place to mitigate these risks..
summarised_answer: 1. Loss of sensitive financial data due to security breaches in cloud service providers.
2. Single point of failure due to reliance on a single cloud service provider.
3. Inability to access critical financial data and services due to disruptions in the internet.
4. Adequate backup and recovery plans must be in place to mitigate risks associated with cloud computing.
summarised_input: 1. The US Treasury has launched a new oversight committee called the Cloud Executive Steering Group.

2. The FBIIC report from the Treasury’s Financial and Banking Information Infrastructure Committee suggests that regulators are getting nervous about the systemic financial risks emanating from the cloud.
3. The report notes that more than 90% of the members of the American Bankers Association are shifting activity on to the cloud, although more than 80% say this is at an early stage.
4. The FBIIC calculates that cloud usage will triple by 2025.
5. Financial regulators are ill-equipped to handle the explosive growth of cloud computing, since they have historically hired economists, not techies.

definition: In this task, you're given a news article. context: For more than a decade, the leadership of the World Bank has been riddled with controversy. The two most recent presidents, Dr Kim Jim Yong and Mr David Malpass, resigned before completing their full terms. Dr Kim, a physician who was appointed in 2012, presided over a chaotic reorganisation of the bank and lost the confidence of its staff, while Mr Malpass, a former Treasury department official from the Trump administration, was severely criticised by scientists, non-governmental organisations (NGOs) and members of the US Congress for failing to address the climate crisis, and indeed, for being a climate denier.

The World Bank now has a new president, Mr Ajay Banga, an American citizen of Indian origin. The United States is the largest shareholder of the World Bank and has always appointed its president, even though it has no formal mandate to do so.

In recent years, developing countries – which make up the majority of the bank’s clients – NGOs, former senior bank officials and even the bank’s staff association have been lobbying for the bank to be led by someone other than an American male. One of their arguments is that since promoting development is the core mission of the bank, its leader should be drawn from among candidates from developing countries who have experience and expertise in tackling development-related challenges.

The Biden administration has finessed the issue by choosing Mr Banga, who was born and educated in India, and has extensive international experience, having worked with multinational enterprises, including Nestle, Citibank, and more recently, Mastercard, where he was chief executive – at each of which, his achievements were impressive. As a consummate financial manager, a champion of diversity, a supporter of climate activism and well-versed in many of the challenges facing the developing world, he has been cautiously welcomed by the bank’s stakeholders, notwithstanding the fact that he is yet another American male.

Mr Banga will have his work cut out. He takes charge at a time of slowing global growth, deepening poverty in the wake of the Covid-19 pandemic, a serious debt crisis in the developing world, and more frequent climate shocks. He has pledged to leverage the bank’s balance sheet to catalyse additional finance from partners, including other multilateral lenders, the private sector and NGOs. In addition, he would need to orchestrate a capital increase for the bank as well as governance reforms to ensure developing countries have a bigger say in its operations and priorities.

He deserves all possible support from the bank’s stakeholders. But they should not let up on their mission to ensure that the leadership of the bank is truly merit-based, internationally sourced and not a continuing monopoly of the US.
question: 1. What are the main reasons behind the controversy in the leadership of the World Bank over the past decade?
answer: The controversy in the leadership of the World Bank over the past decade can be attributed to several factors. Firstly, the World Bank has been criticized for promoting neoliberal economic policies that prioritize market-oriented solutions over social welfare and development. This approach has been blamed for exacerbating poverty and inequality in many countries.

Secondly, the World Bank has faced allegations of corruption and lack of transparency in its operations. This has raised concerns about the bank's ability to effectively manage its funds and deliver development projects.

Lastly, the World Bank has been challenged for its role in promoting globalization and the interests of large corporations. Critics argue that this has resulted in a disproportionate focus on private sector-led development, at the expense of public goods and services.

Overall, the controversy surrounding the World Bank's leadership reflects broader debates about the role of the international financial institutions in shaping global economic policies and development priorities.
summarised_answer: 1. The World Bank has been criticized for promoting neoliberal economic policies that prioritize market-oriented solutions over social welfare and development.
2. The World Bank has faced allegations of corruption and lack of transparency in its operations.
3. The World Bank has been challenged for its role in promoting globalization and the interests of large corporations.

4. The controversy surrounding the World Bank's leadership reflects broader debates about the role of the international financial institutions in shaping global economic policies and development priorities.
summarised_input: 1. The leadership of the World Bank has been controversial for more than a decade.
2. The United States is the largest shareholder of the World Bank and has always appointed its president.
3. Developing countries, NGOs, former senior bank officials, and the bank’s staff association have been lobbying for the bank to be led by someone other than an American male.
4. The Biden administration has chosen Mr Ajay Banga, an American citizen of Indian origin, as the new president of the World Bank.

5. Mr Banga has promised to leverage the bank’s balance sheet to catalyse additional finance from partners, including other multilateral lenders, the private sector, and NGOs, and to orchestrate a capital increase for the bank and governance reforms to ensure developing countries have a bigger say in its operations and priorities.

question: 5. How can the leadership of the World Bank be made more merit-based, internationally sourced, and not a continuing monopoly
answer: Claim 1: The leadership of the World Bank should be more merit-based and sourced internationally to ensure that the organization is guided by the most qualified and capable individuals.

To make the leadership of the World Bank more merit-based and internationally sourced, the organization can adopt a more transparent and competitive recruitment process. This can include creating a pool of qualified candidates from diverse backgrounds and regions, conducting thorough and fair interviews and evaluations, and considering a broader range of candidates beyond the traditional pool of development experts. By doing so, the World Bank can ensure that its leadership is composed of individuals who possess the necessary skills, knowledge, and experience to effectively lead the organization in achieving its goals.
Claim 2: The current monopoly of the United States on the leadership of the World Bank should be discontinued to promote greater diversity and representation.

The current monopoly of the United States on the leadership of the World Bank has been criticized for limiting the diversity and representation of the organization. By discontinuing this monopoly, the World Bank can open up opportunities for individuals from other countries to be considered for leadership positions. This can promote greater diversity and representation, as well as ensure that the organization is better equipped to address the needs and challenges of a globalized world.
Claim 3: The leadership of the World Bank should not be a continuing monopoly to ensure that the organization remains accountable and responsive to the needs of its member countries.

The continuing monopoly of the United States on the leadership of the World Bank has been criticized for limiting the accountability and responsiveness of the organization. By not making the leadership a continuing monopoly, the World Bank can ensure that it remains accountable and responsive to the needs of its member countries. This can be achieved by creating a more diverse and competitive pool of candidates for leadership positions, and by ensuring that the selection process is transparent and fair. By doing so, the World Bank can better serve its member countries and promote sustainable development worldwide.

2. The current monopoly of the United States on the leadership of the World Bank should be discontinued to promote diversity and representation.
3. The leadership of the World Bank should not be a continuing monopoly to ensure accountability and responsiveness to member countries.

context: Simone Peinkofer
E-commerce may make shopping more convenient, but it has a dark side that most consumers never see.

Say you order an electric toothbrush for Father’s Day and two shirts for yourself from Amazon. You unpack your order and discover that the electric toothbrush will not charge, and only one shirt fits you. So, you decide to return the unwanted shirt and the electric toothbrush.
Returns like this might seem simple, and often they are free for the consumer. But managing those returns can get costly for retailers, so much so that many returned items are simply thrown out.

In 2022, returns cost retailers about US$816 billion (S$1.1 trillion) in lost sales. That is nearly as much as what the United States spent on public schools and almost twice the cost of returns in 2020. The return process, with transportation and packaging, also generated about 24 million tonnes of planet-warming carbon dioxide emissions in 2022.
Together, costs and emissions create a sustainability problem for retailers and the planet.
As a supply chain management researcher, I follow developments in retail logistics. Let’s take a closer look inside the black box of product returns.
So, you repackaged your unwanted shirt and the electric toothbrush and drove them to UPS, which has an agreement with Amazon for free returns. Now what?

UPS transports those items to the retailer’s warehouses dedicated to processing returns. This step of the process costs the retailer money – 66 per cent of the cost of a US$50 item by one estimate – and emits carbon dioxide as trucks and planes carry items hundreds of kilometres. The plastic, paper or cardboard from the return package becomes waste.

Processing a return takes two to three times longer than initially shipping the item – it has to be unpacked, inspected, repacked and rerouted. That adds more to the cost to the company, especially in a tight labour market. Workers have to manually unpack the items, inspect them and, based on the return reason, decide what will happen next.
If a warehouse worker decides the shirt in our example can be resold, the shirt will be repackaged and sent to another warehouse.
Once another consumer orders the shirt, it will be ready to be packed and shipped.

In-store returns can significantly cut warehouse and transportation costs, but driving to a bricks-and-mortar store might not be convenient for the consumer. Only about a quarter of online purchases are returned in person to the store.

If the item is defective, like the electric toothbrush in our example, the warehouse worker might send it back to the manufacturer for fixing and refurbishing. It would be repackaged and loaded on a truck and possibly a plane to be sent to the manufacturer, leading to more carbon dioxide emissions.
If the electric toothbrush can be repaired, the refurbished product is ready to be sold into the consumer market again – often at a lower price.
Refurbishing returned products helps to achieve a closed-loop supply chain where products are reused rather than disposed of as waste, making the process more sustainable than buying a new item.
Sometimes, however, repairs cost more than the product can be resold for. When it is more expensive to restock or refurbish a product, it may be cheaper for the retailer to throw the item away.

If the company cannot resell the shirt or refurbish the electric toothbrush economically, the outlook for these items is grim. Some are sold in bulk to discount stores. Often, returned products simply end up in landfills, sometimes overseas.

In 2019, about 2.3 million tonnes of waste from returns were sent to landfills, according to an estimate by return technology platform Optoro. By 2022, the estimated waste had more than doubled to about 4.74 million tonnes.

In the past, customers who wanted to return items by mail were often expected to do so on their own dime. That changed after Amazon began offering free returns and providing easy-to-use drop-off locations at UPS or Kohl’s stores. Other retailers followed suit to compete, with many seeing free returns as a way to keep shoppers coming back.
But that pendulum may be starting to swing back. The percentage of retailers charging to ship returns increased from 33 per cent to 41 per cent in 2022.
Retailers are trying several other techniques to lower the return rate, waste and losses, which ultimately come back to consumers in the form of higher prices.
Some retailers have shortened the return window, limited frequent returns, or stopped offering free returns.
Other strategies include virtual dressing rooms and clearer fitting guides, which can help reduce clothing returns, as can high-quality photos and videos that reflect size and colour accurately.
If consumers use those tools and pay attention to sizing, they can help cut down on retail’s growing climate footprint.

4. The author calls for immediate action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and transition to renewable energy sources.
5. The article emphasizes the importance of individual actions, such as reducing energy consumption and waste, as well as government and corporate actions, in addressing climate change.

2. Returns can be costly for retailers, leading to lost sales and environmental impacts.
3. Returns create a sustainability problem for retailers and the planet.
4. The return process, including transportation and packaging, generates carbon dioxide emissions.

If consumers use those tools and pay attention to sizing, they can help cut down on retail’s growing climate footprint.
question: 2. How much did returns cost retailers in 2022?
answer: In 2022, returns cost retailers a significant amount of money.
The exact amount varies depending on the source, but it is estimated that retailers in the United States lost between $30 billion and $50 billion due to returns.
This is a significant increase from previous years and is attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic, which disrupted supply chains and led to longer delivery times.
Retailers have also been forced to bear the costs of handling and processing returns, which can be time-consuming and expensive.

As a result, retailers are exploring new ways to reduce the number of returns, such as offering more flexible return policies and improving the customer experience to encourage customers to keep their purchases..
summarised_answer: 1. Retailers in the United States lost between $30 billion and $50 billion due to returns in 2022.
2. The COVID-19 pandemic is attributed to the significant increase in return costs.
3. Retailers have had to bear the costs of handling and processing returns.
4. Retailers are exploring new ways to reduce the number of returns, such as offering more flexible return policies and improving the customer experience.

question: 4. How do retailers manage returns, and what are the associated costs and emissions?
answer: Claim 1: Retailers manage returns through a combination of in-store and online return processes.
Claim 2: The costs associated with returns can vary depending on the type of product and the reason for the return.
Claim 3: The emissions associated with returns can be reduced through the use of sustainable shipping methods and efficient logistics practices.

Retailers manage returns through a combination of in-store and online return processes. In-store returns are typically handled through the customer returning the item to the store, while online returns are processed through the mail or through a prepaid shipping label provided by the retailer. Retailers may also offer in-store credit or store credit as a form of return.

The costs associated with returns can vary depending on the type of product and the reason for the return. For example, returns of perishable items or items with hygiene concerns may incur higher costs due to the need for disposal or sanitation. Returns for defective or incorrect items may also result in higher costs for the retailer.

The emissions associated with returns can be reduced through the use of sustainable shipping methods and efficient logistics practices. Retailers can use carbon-neutral shipping methods, such as sea freight or rail, to reduce emissions. Additionally, efficient logistics practices, such as optimizing delivery routes and reducing packaging waste, can also help to reduce emissions associated with returns.
summarised_answer: 1. Retailers manage returns through a combination of in-store and online return processes.
2. The costs associated with returns can vary depending on the type of product and the reason for the return.
3. The emissions associated with returns can be reduced through the use of sustainable shipping methods and efficient logistics practices.

4. The return process, including transportation and packaging, generates carbon dioxide emissions.

question: 5. What are some strategies retailers are using to reduce return rates, waste, and losses?
answer: 1. Retailers are implementing advanced inventory management systems to accurately forecast demand and reduce stockouts and overstocking. This helps to minimize waste by ensuring that the right products are available in the right quantities, while also reducing return rates by providing customers with the products they are looking for.

2. Retailers are offering more flexible return policies, such as longer return periods and easier return processes, to reduce the number of returns and make it more convenient for customers to return products if necessary. This helps to minimize waste by reducing the number of returned products that need to be liquidated, while also reducing losses by making it easier for customers to return products and receive a refund.

3. Retailers are investing in technology and automation to streamline the returns process and reduce manual handling, which can reduce the risk of damage to products and minimize waste. This can include automated sorting systems, robotic picking and packing, and automated shipping and logistics. By reducing waste and losses, retailers can improve their bottom line and enhance their reputation with customers.
summarised_answer: 1. Advanced inventory management systems are implemented to forecast demand and reduce stockouts and overstocking.
2. Flexible return policies are offered to reduce the number of returns and make it convenient for customers.
3. Technology and automation are invested in to streamline the returns process and reduce waste.

context: It is extremely troubling that a recent study, conducted by Duke-NUS Medical School and the Institute of Mental Health (IMH), has suggested that anxiety and depression symptoms among people here could be costing Singapore nearly $16 billion a year, or about 2.9 per cent of the nation’s gross domestic product. This is so as a result of absenteeism, reduced productivity, and the use of healthcare resources. According to the researchers, this is the first study after the coronavirus pandemic that estimates the prevalence of, and quantifies the financial cost of, depression and anxiety symptoms among Singaporean adults. While the economic and social dislocation produced by Covid-19 expectedly produced a decline in mental health, what is worrying is that even the national recovery from that period of stress did not produce better results in the survey, which covered 5,725 Singaporeans above 21 years old between April and June 2022. Clearly, mental health is an issue that Singapore must grapple with urgently.

The lesson to be drawn from the survey is the need to treat mental health on a par with physical health. Singapore possesses admirable assets by way of its hospitals, both public and private, its step-down care facilities, its polyclinics, its general practitioners, and its specialists. They cater to the physical well-being of residents in a way that justifies Singapore’s reputation for First World healthcare.
